Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6B-KMC1-JCMN-Y3C3-00000-00Ajit Pai Coddles Big Telecom, Demonizes Silicon Valley2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisAjit Pai Coddles Big Telecom, Demonizes Silicon ValleyKarl Bode

Sep 05, 2018( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) ; To be very clear there's no shortage of legitimate criticism aimed at giants like Facebook and Google for their inconsistent policies, repeated privacy snafus, and incessantly-incompetent[1] public relations skills. That said, a large chunk of the push to "do something" about Google, Facebook and Twitter's supposed assault on free speech is also little more than wet nonsense[2] driven by people who don't understand how the internet or First Amendment work[3]. And a lot of the recent breathless hyperventilation in DC[4] and vilification of "big tech" is being driven by the telecom sector, which has spent years demanding that their broken and uncompetitive monopoly market be mindlessly deregulated, while the healthier, more competitive online content and ad space face onerous new regulations[5]. We've discussed at length how the telecom industry has grown bored with the slow, steady profit made from upgrading and running broadband networks[6], and has shifted its focus toward the sexier realm of online advertising. Granted, when large ISPs try to directly compete in that space they tend to fall flat on their faces[7], since running government-pampered monopolies has dulled their innovative and competitive edge. As a result, the Comcast/AT...erizon version of "competition" usually involves two things they're actually good at: cheating by distorting the playing field[8] (aka net neutrality violations) and lobbying.

The motivation here (money) isn't really mysterious. Cable lobbyists routinely call for regulation of[9] companies they're trying to compete with in the online ad space, and loyal policymakers and lawmakers are frequently happy to oblige[10] to keep campaign contributions flowing. Telecom executives like to pretend this is just fair play, given Netflix and Google's (long since dead[11]) support of net neutrality. The difference: ISPs really were trying to use their broadband monopolies to harm competitors, and Google and Netflix's arguments were largely being made in good faith. There's no good faith ISP arguments occurring here. ISPs don't actually care about privacy, transparency, or your right to spread hate on Twitter. And ISP BFFs like Ajit Pai have long demonized Silicon Valley giants[12] by using straight up nonsense[13] in order to make their argument (like the time he tried to claim a run of the mill Netflix CDN was a network neutrality violation[14]). All while turning a blind eye to ample problems in the telecom sector. This inconsistency was again on proud display this week in a post by Pai over at Medium[15] ahead of this week's Silicon Valley hearings. In it, Pai laments all manner of problems with Silicon Valley giants, from their disdain for privacy, to a lack of total transparency. You'll notice that most of the concerns Pai expresses were comically-absent as he dismantled popular net neutrality (and ISP transparency[16]) protections last fall:"Are these tech giants running impartial digital platforms over which they don't exercise editorial judgment when it comes to content? Or do they in fact decide what speech is allowed and what is not and discriminate based on ideology and/or political affiliation? And again, going back to the first point: where is the transparency?"Pai's sudden interest in transparency is downright adorable. But you'd have to be blind not to notice how the things Pai demonizes Silicon Valley for pale in comparison to many of the things we've seen in the telecom sector[17]. You'd also have to be blind not to notice how Pai's arguments perfectly mirror the telecom industry lobbying talking points[18] accidentally leaked to us last week by US Telecom. From ISPs efforts to charge customers more for privacy[19] to using bullshit fees to jack up your bill[20], Pai never bats an eyelash when AT...r Comcast engages in this kind of behavior, yet hyperventilates when talking about Google, Facebook, and Twitter doing things notably less terrible (or hallucinated entirely). Pai spent the last five years insisting that ISPs shouldn't face "burdensome regulations," despite the fact ISPs like Comcast operate natural monopolies. Yet here he is, advocating for new regulatory restrictions to be foisted upon ISP competitors who actually do face competition:"The public deserves to know more about how these companies operate. And we need to seriously think about whether the time has come for these companies to abide by new transparency obligations. After all, just as is the case with respect to broadband providers, consumers need accurate information in order to make educated choices about whether and how to use these tech giants' platforms."Part of the problem is that this conversation on what to do about Facebook, Google and Twitter has been infected by our idiotic need to apply partisanship to fucking everything, regardless of whether it makes intellectual sense. Net neutrality, for example, has long been played up as a "partisan" issue by ISPs to sow dissent and derail consensus, despite the fact that an overwhelming bipartisan majority of Americans[21] support it. Here too, ISPs are using baseless, inconsistent, and inflammatory rhetoric[22] to enflame partisan divides and censorship fears with an eye on hampering competitors. There's absolutely a legitimate conversation to be had here in terms of what to do about privacy and speech in the Facebook and Twitter era. And that may or may not involve crafting new regulations. But it might be nice if people wised up to the fact that a huge swath of the conversation is being dictated not by parties acting in good faith with a genuine eye on valid solutions, but by telecom monopolies eager to pee in the discourse pool simply to fatten their wallets.Permalink[23] | Comments[24] | Email This Story[25] [ 1]: urn:contentItem:5R5M-DS71-JBG3-60JH-00000-00Ajit Pai Nears His Biggest Win With Net Neutrality Repeal2017-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYAjit Pai Nears His Biggest Win With Net Neutrality RepealCECILIA KANG

Erasing the Obama-era internet rules on Thursday would help secure Mr. Pai’s reputation as one of the most efficient F.C.C. leaders in decades.

WASHINGTON — Small tech companies, consumer groups and many celebrities have been up in arms for weeks about a proposal at the Federal Communications Commission to dismantle landmark rules that guarantee an open internet.

But in one speech, Ajit Pai, the chairman of the agency, called the complaints “hysteria” and “hot air.” In another, he dismissed criticism that by pushing the change, he was doing the bidding of companies like Verizon, his former employer. He joked that his nightmare scenario would be refereeing a dispute between Verizon and Sinclair Broadcasting, another company he has been accused of helping with his policies.

“How do you choose,” he said, “between a longtime love and a newfound crush?”

The agency was expected to vote on Thursday to dismantle the so-called net neutrality rules, which prohibit internet service providers from blocking or charging websites for higher quality delivery to consumers. It would also dial back the stance established during the Obama administration that broadband should be regulated like a utility. The three Republican commissioners, including Mr. Pai, have said they will vote for the proposal, outnumbering the two Democratic commissioners.

Passing the plan would be the biggest victory in Mr. Pai’s eventful 11-month tenure as the head of the F.C.C. Under his leadership, the agency has already opened the door for more media mergers, curtailed a high-speed internet program for low-income families and allowed broadband providers to raise rates to business customers.

All of this activity has made Mr. Pai, 44, a former lawyer for Verizon and a longtime government bureaucrat, the target of many angry protests. In recent days, government officials — including 18 state attorneys generals and dozens of Democratic members of Congress — have asked the F.C.C. to delay the vote. On Wednesday,   the attorneys general   said that many of the 23 million public comments that had been filed to the agency about net neutrality appeared to be fraudulent. Mr. Pai has ignored the delay requests.

But Mr. Pai’s changes have also made him a pivotal official in the Trump administration’s rush to shed regulations. The effects of his decisions have rippled across the industries Mr. Pai oversees. The looser rules on media ownership, for example, has enabledSinclair Broadcasting’s $3.9 billion bid for Tribune.

“Ajit Pai has the potential to be one of most consequential commissioners in the agency’s history,” said Gus Hurwitz, an assistant professor at the University of Nebraska College of Law, who is an expert in telecom policy and who supports Mr. Pai’s proposal.

Even Mr. Pai’s detractors acknowledge that Mr. Pai has been efficient at moving his agenda. Mark Cooper, a staff member of Consumer Federation of America, said Mr. Pai has far outpaced his recent predecessors, even if Mr. Cooper does not agree with those efforts.

“In every way,” Mr. Cooper said, “his decisions are bad for consumers and good for big corporations.”

Mr. Pai declined to be interviewed for this article. But in a statement, the F.C.C. said that he “has been focused on making the agency more transparent, closing the digital divide, and updating the Commission’s rules to reflect the modern communications marketplace.”

The agency added that “the F.C.C. has modernized its rules across a wide range of areas to encourage more competition and innovation.”

Mr. Pai’s deregulatory fervor began well before the presidential election and his nomination by President Trump.

The child of immigrants from India who settled in Kansas, Mr. Pai was lauded by Republicans and Democrats when he was appointed in 2011 by President Obama to the F.C.C. Lawmakers and public interest groups hoped the young nominee would bring a greater appreciation for how communications was shifting online than past commissioners.

But for five years as a minority member of the F.C.C., Mr. Pai consistently voted against regulations such as those limiting business broadband prices and a broadband subsidy for low-income Americans. He complained that the agency’s Democratic leaders, including Tom Wheeler, were too heavy-handed with companies.

The biggest offense, in his opinion, were the 2015 net neutrality rules, which included the declaration that broadband would be subject to more utility-style rules. He said the regulations would burden the fast-growing high-speed internet market. In dissenting comments during the debate over the rules, he echoed the arguments of telecom companies that the F.C.C.’s net neutrality rules made it hard for telecoms to expand their networks, leading to less innovation in business plans and would eventually harm the economy.

He also accused the White House of presidential interference in the activities of the F.C.C., an independent agency. Mr. Pai said that the agency had taken its direction only after President Obama posted a video in favor of the net neutrality rules.

“We are flip-flopping for one reason and one reason alone,” he said at the time. “President Obama told us to do so.”

Mr. Pai’s consistent opposition attracted supporters from free-market think tanks and conservative commentators like Rush Limbaugh and Roger Stone, a former Trump adviser who recently praised the proposal to scrap net neutrality rules. Mr. Pai became a frequent guest on Fox News and other conservative media and was praised in the editorial pages of The Wall Street Journal.

“How fortunately ironic that it is Ajit Pai himself, as the Trump-appointed chair of the F.C.C., that will pull the plug on the ill-intended act called ‘net neutrality,’” Mr. Stone wrote recently in The Daily Caller.

Supporters of net neutrality argue that telecom companies want to become the gatekeepers of the internet, deciding whether sites have access to fast or slow connections. But Mr. Pai has responded by saying the bigger threat is from the big tech companies. Google, Twitter and Facebook, he argues, can deprive consumers of free expression.

He says Twitter, for example, sometimes wrongly suspends users just because they do not share the same views as the company.

“Let’s not kid ourselves,” Mr. Pai said last month at an event sponsored by the R Street Institute, a free markets think tank. “When it comes to an open internet, Twitter is part of the problem.”

PHOTOS: Under Ajit Pai, the Federal Communications Commission has moved aggressively to scale back regulations. (PHOTOGRAPH BY ERIC THAYER FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES); PHOTO (PHOTOGRAPH BY CHRISTOPHER GREGORY FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W46-CPD1-F03R-N05T-00000-00'Alabama Bill at Odds With Public Consensus on Abortion'2019-05-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexis'Alabama Bill at Odds With Public Consensus on Abortion'Howard Bashman

May 15, 2019( How Appealing: https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com Delivered by Newstex) ;;;;;;; 'Title IX investigation ends with IU Maurer professor's departure': Marilyn Odendahl of The Indiana Lawyer has this report[1]. Posted at 7:10 PM [2] by Howard Bashman[3] 'The Anti-monopoly Backlash Reaches the Supreme Court; In a 5-4 decision, the justices decided not to stand in the way of reining in Big Tech': Law professor Eric Posner[4] has this essay[5] online at The Atlantic. Posted at 6:55 PM [6] by Howard Bashman[7] 'Federal Circuit has No Opinion; Senju Asks the Supreme Court for Its': Dennis Crouch has this post[8] at his 'Patently-O' blog. Posted at 6:53 PM [9] by Howard Bashman[10] 'At Supreme Court hearing on lame-duck laws, conservative justices skeptical of claims GOP acted improperly': Patrick Marley of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel has this report[11]. Riley Vetterkind of The Wisconsin State Journal reports that 'Conservative justices signal skepticism of challenge to lame-duck laws[12].' And Shawn Johnson of Wisconsin Public Radio reports that 'Supreme Court's Conservatives Strike Skeptical Tone During Lame-Duck Case Arguments; Lawsuit Challenges December's Lame-Duck Session[13].' Posted at 6:48 PM [14] by Howard Bashman[15] 'Alabama's Extremist Abortion Bill Ruins John Roberts' Roe Plan; SCOTUS was all teed up to quietly gut America's abortion rights; Then Alabama happened': Dahlia Lithwick has this jurisprudence essay[16] online at Slate.

And online at ThinkProgress, Ian Millhiser has an essay titled 'Supreme Court is poised to kill Roe v. Wade; If you think this Supreme Court won't kill Roe v. Wade in an election year, you're fooling yourself[17].' Posted at 6:28 PM [18] by Howard Bashman[19] 'Abortion restrictions? Partisan election maps? Same-sex wedding cakes? Supreme Court has heard it all before.' Richard Wolf of USA Today has this report[20]. Posted at 6:22 PM [21] by Howard Bashman[22] 'Gov. Kay Ivey signs near-total abortion ban into law': Brian Lyman of The Montgomery Advertiser has this report[23]. Posted at 6:20 PM [24] by Howard Bashman[25] 'Alabama Bill at Odds With Public Consensus on Abortion': Lydia Saad of Gallup has this report[26]. Posted at 6:18 PM [27] by Howard Bashman[28] 'Alabama Aims Squarely at Roe, but the Supreme Court May Prefer Glancing Blows': Adam Liptak of The New York Times has this report[29]. Robert Barnes of The Washington Post reports that 'The race to overturn Roe v. Wade looks to a Supreme Court that prefers gradual change[30].' Ronn Blitzer of Fox News reports that 'Abortion foes eye Supreme Court showdown in wake of Alabama ban[31].' And at Vox, Anna North has an article headlined 'Alabama Republicans want to overturn Roe v. Wade. Their strategy could backfire. The Alabama abortion ban's lack of exceptions for rape or incest could be its downfall[32].' Posted at 6:12 PM [33] by Howard Bashman[34] 'Kenneth Lee — Nominee to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit': Harsh Voruganti has this post[35] at his blog, 'The Vetting Room.' Posted at 5:08 PM [36] by Howard Bashman[37] ''Heartbeat' Abortion Bans Are Going Nowhere Before 2020; State laws restricting abortion early in pregnancy are still unconstitutional, and there's no incentive for the Supreme Court to act quickly to change that': Law professor Noah Feldman[38] has this essay[39] online at Bloomberg Opinion. Posted at 4:46 PM [40] by Howard Bashman[41] 'Sen. Mitt Romney votes against Trump judicial pick over comments he made about Obama': Thomas Burr of The Salt Lake Tribune has this report[42]. And Burgess Everett of Politico reports that 'Romney rejects Trump judicial pick who smeared Obama[43].' Posted at 4:26 PM [44] by Howard Bashman[45] 'Springtime for Antitrust Lawyers: Justice Kavanaugh joins the liberals to open a new avenue for lawsuits.' This editorial[46] appeared in yesterday's edition of The Wall Street Journal. And online at Bloomberg Opinion, law professor Noah Feldman[47] has an essay titled 'Kavanaugh Takes a Shot at Apple, and Big Tech Should Take Note; The Supreme Court is more open to antitrust litigation if the newest justice is willing to join liberals on this issue[48].' Posted at 4:23 PM [49] by Howard Bashman[50] 'Supreme Court Justice Gascon releases a statement on his health after his disappearance': Sean Fine of The Toronto Globe and Mail has this report[51]. Tonda MacCharles of The Toronto Star reports that 'Supreme Court justice says he had panic attack before going missing[52].' Peter Zimonjic of CBC News reports that 'Supreme Court Justice Gascon attributes disappearance to depression, anxiety[53].' And The Canadian Press has a report headlined 'Clement Gascon, high court justice who went missing, says he had panic attack; Gascon, who has already announced plans to retire, says he has long dealt with depression and anxiety[54].' Yesterday, the Supreme Court of Canada[55] issued this news release[56] on the matter. Posted at 4:08 PM [57] by Howard Bashman[58] 'A few thoughts on en banc oral argument: splitting time, the Soliloquy Rule, and flip flops somehow.' Matthew Stiegler has this post[59] at his 'CA3blog.' Posted at 4:00 PM [60] by Howard Bashman[61] 'Ask the author: 'So Long, Earl.'' At 'SCOTUSblog,' Andrew Hamm has this interview[62] with Michael Bobelian, author of 'Battle for the Marble Palace: Abe Fortas, Earl Warren, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, and the Forging of the Modern Supreme Court[63].' Posted at 1:57 PM [64] by Howard Bashman[65] 'Justice Department says FDA 'lacks jurisdiction' over death-penalty drugs': Laurie McGinley and Mark Berman of The Washington Post have this report[66]. And in today's edition of The New York Times, Charlie Savage has an article headlined 'Justice Dept. Stops F.D.A. From Regulating Death-Penalty Drugs[67].' Posted at 12:45 PM [68] by Howard Bashman[69] 'New witness list filed in Dan Markel murder case': Julie Montanaro of CBS affiliate WCTV Eyewitness News in Tallahassee has this report[70]. Posted at 12:05 PM [71] by Howard Bashman[72] 'Acknowledging His Own Misconduct: Most professors found to have violated Title IX policies don't share it with the world; This one did, as he resigned.' Colleen Flaherty of Inside Higher Ed has this report[73]. Posted at 12:02 PM [74] by Howard Bashman[75] 'Opinion analysis: Hyatt fulfills expectations in a surprising way.' Richard M. Re has this guest post[76] at 'SCOTUSblog.' Posted at 11:55 AM [77] by Howard Bashman[78] 'Experience in the Courtroom, Strong Role Models Give Grad Her Start; Women Role Models Helped Kendall Burchard '19 Along the Path': Eric Williamson of the University of Virginia School of Law has this report[79]. Posted at 11:50 AM [80] by Howard Bashman[81] 'An initial look at Peter Phipps, Trump's next Third Circuit nominee': Matthew Stiegler has this post[82] at his 'CA3blog.' Posted at 8:40 AM [83] by Howard Bashman[84] 'Court Says FEC Deadlocks Need No Second-Guessing By Judges': Kenneth P. Doyle of Bloomberg Law has this report[85] (subscription required for full access). And at his 'Election Law Blog,' Rick Hasen has a post titled 'DC Circuit Denies En Banc Consideration in Crew v. FEC Case, Essentially Giving Republican Commissioners Unfettered Ability to Block All Campaign Finance Enforcement Matters with No Judicial Review of the Decision[86].' You can access yesterday's order of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit[87] denying rehearing en banc, and the opinions concurring in and dissenting from that denial, at this link[88]. Posted at 8:34 AM [89] by Howard Bashman[90] 'I write separately to express my continued opposition to the use of conduct for which a defendant was acquitted to increase the length of that person's sentence.' So wrote D.C. Circuit[91] Judge Patricia A. Millett[92] in a concurring opinion[93] yesterday issued in an appeal involving a noteworthy criminal defendant[94]. urn:contentItem:52WJ-W6Y1-JCBJ-K2C4-00000-00Alabama: HIGHLIGHTS-UPDATE 1-U.S. hedge funds favor gold, oil.2011-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisAlabama: HIGHLIGHTS-UPDATE 1-U.S. hedge funds favor gold, oil.

Alabama: The State of Alabama has issued following press release:

Coatue Management's Sina exposure soars to 2.9 mln shrs

* Green Mountain Coffee still stock-market darling (Updates with Sina, Green Mountain Coffee and Visa)

NEW YORK/BOSTON, May 16 (Reuters) - In the wake of the commoditiesrout, one of the biggest questions in the hedge-fund world is: Who was left holding the bag in silver, oil and other commodity-related stocks?

Top hedge-fund managers in the United States are providing possible answers as they file a required breakout of their stock holdings inthe first quarter.

But the release of these filings, known as 13F's and due May 16, comes with a big caveat. The positions disclosed by managers show how their portfolios looked at the end of the first quarter -- a lifetimein the markets, and well before the bloodbath in commodities began on May 3.

Still, the filings offer a window on which funds were big in mining stocks or exchange-traded funds that track silver, gold and oil. The filings also reveal which big tech names top funds were moving in and out of during the first quarter.

Filings also show which stocks became the darling of the moment for hedge funds. In the fourth quarter of 2010, there was a mad rush byhedge funds into Green Mountain Coffee Roasters Inc (GMCR.O), which has risen more than 125 percent so far this year.

Technology-oriented hedge fund Coatue Management LLC, for example,raised its stake in Green Mountain during the first three months of the year to 4.3 million shares from 4 million.

The filings reveal whether hedge funds are still buzzing with a caffeine high or looking to cash in some profits and put their dollars elsewhere.

Also, the filings show whether hedge funds remain bullish on a rebound of the financial sector as many loaded up last year on shares ofCitigroup (C.N), Bank of America (BAC.N) and Wells Fargo(WFC.N).

Here are highlights of some of the moves in and out of stocks and sectors that fund mangers made during the first quarter.

GOLD

Seth Klarman's Baupost Group LLC opened a new position in Allied Nevada Gold Corp(ANV.A), a Reno, Nevada-based miner whose shares climbed 35 percent in the first quarter after soaring almost 75 percent in 2010 as gold prices jumped.

Baupost held 2.46 million shares of AlliedNevada valued at $87.2 million on March 31, regulatory filings show.

OIL AND GAS

Paul Tudor Jones' Tudor Investment Corp increased its stake in ExxonMobil (XOM.N) to 53,100 shares from 6,500 shares. Shares of the U.S. energy company have risen more than 15 percent in the first quarter.

COMPUTER SERVICES

Coatue Management made some adjustments in its computer services holdings by sharply raising its stake in Sina Corp. (SINA.O), owner ofChina's third most-visited website and the Twitter-like Weibo service, to 2.9 million shares from 451,000. The fund manager also raised its holdings of Google (GOOG.O). Coatue's holdings of Apple (AAPL.O) were mostly unchanged. It trimmed Qualcomm Inc (QCOM.O) to 6.3 millionshares from 7 million shares.

FINANCIAL SERVICES

Coatue, which owned 2 million shares of Citigroup at the end of the fourth quarter, did not list the bank in its holdings at the end ofthe first quarter.

PHARMA

Thomas Steyer's Farallon Capital Management's largest holding at the end of the first quarter was Genzyme Corp (GENZ.MX), which was acquired by France's Sanofi (SASY.PA) in a $20 billion deal that closed in early April.

In the period, Farallon added roughly 4.1 million shares of Genzyme.

CONSUMER

Farallon roughly doubled its stake in retailer Target (TGT.N) to 3.46 million shares, from 1.51 million shares in the prior quarter.

Chase Coleman's Tiger Global Management reduced its stake in credit card giant Visa (V.N) 845,500 shares. The fund ended the first quarter reporting that it held 1.5 million shares of Visa. (Reporting by Herbert Lash, Svea Herbst-Bayliss, Aaron Pressman and Ross Kerber;

For more information Please Visit: http://www.reuters.com/

May 15, 2019( How Appealing: https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com Delivered by Newstex) ;;;;;;; 'Title IX investigation ends with IU Maurer professor's departure': Marilyn Odendahl of The Indiana Lawyer has this report[1]. Posted at 7:10 PM [2] by Howard Bashman[3] 'The Anti-monopoly Backlash Reaches the Supreme Court; In a 5-4 decision, the justices decided not to stand in the way of reining in Big Tech': Law professor Eric Posner[4] has this essay[5] online at The Atlantic. Posted at 6:55 PM [6] by Howard Bashman[7] 'Federal Circuit has No Opinion; Senju Asks the Supreme Court for Its': Dennis Crouch has this post[8] at his 'Patently-O' blog. Posted at 6:53 PM [9] by Howard Bashman[10] 'At Supreme Court hearing on lame-duck laws, conservative justices skeptical of claims GOP acted improperly': Patrick Marley of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel has this report[11]. Riley Vetterkind of The Wisconsin State Journal reports that 'Conservative justices signal skepticism of challenge to lame-duck laws[12].' And Shawn Johnson of Wisconsin Public Radio reports that 'Supreme Court's Conservatives Strike Skeptical Tone During Lame-Duck Case Arguments; Lawsuit Challenges December's Lame-Duck Session[13].' Posted at 6:48 PM [14] by Howard Bashman[15] 'Alabama's Extremist Abortion Bill Ruins John Roberts' Roe Plan; SCOTUS was all teed up to quietly gut America's abortion rights; Then Alabama happened': Dahlia Lithwick has this jurisprudence essay[16] online at Slate.

And online at ThinkProgress, Ian Millhiser has an essay titled 'Supreme Court is poised to kill Roe v. Wade; If you think this Supreme Court won't kill Roe v. Wade in an election year, you're fooling yourself[17].' Posted at 6:28 PM [18] by Howard Bashman[19] 'Abortion restrictions? Partisan election maps? Same-sex wedding cakes? Supreme Court has heard it all before.' Richard Wolf of USA Today has this report[20]. Posted at 6:22 PM [21] by Howard Bashman[22] 'Gov. Kay Ivey signs near-total abortion ban into law': Brian Lyman of The Montgomery Advertiser has this report[23]. Posted at 6:20 PM [24] by Howard Bashman[25] 'Alabama Bill at Odds With Public Consensus on Abortion': Lydia Saad of Gallup has this report[26]. Posted at 6:18 PM [27] by Howard Bashman[28] 'Alabama Aims Squarely at Roe, but the Supreme Court May Prefer Glancing Blows': Adam Liptak of The New York Times has this report[29]. Robert Barnes of The Washington Post reports that 'The race to overturn Roe v. Wade looks to a Supreme Court that prefers gradual change[30].' Ronn Blitzer of Fox News reports that 'Abortion foes eye Supreme Court showdown in wake of Alabama ban[31].' And at Vox, Anna North has an article headlined 'Alabama Republicans want to overturn Roe v. Wade. Their strategy could backfire. The Alabama abortion ban's lack of exceptions for rape or incest could be its downfall[32].' Posted at 6:12 PM [33] by Howard Bashman[34] 'Kenneth Lee — Nominee to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit': Harsh Voruganti has this post[35] at his blog, 'The Vetting Room.' Posted at 5:08 PM [36] by Howard Bashman[37] ''Heartbeat' Abortion Bans Are Going Nowhere Before 2020; State laws restricting abortion early in pregnancy are still unconstitutional, and there's no incentive for the Supreme Court to act quickly to change that': Law professor Noah Feldman[38] has this essay[39] online at Bloomberg Opinion. Posted at 4:46 PM [40] by Howard Bashman[41] 'Sen. Mitt Romney votes against Trump judicial pick over comments he made about Obama': Thomas Burr of The Salt Lake Tribune has this report[42]. And Burgess Everett of Politico reports that 'Romney rejects Trump judicial pick who smeared Obama[43].' Posted at 4:26 PM [44] by Howard Bashman[45] 'Springtime for Antitrust Lawyers: Justice Kavanaugh joins the liberals to open a new avenue for lawsuits.' This editorial[46] appeared in yesterday's edition of The Wall Street Journal. And online at Bloomberg Opinion, law professor Noah Feldman[47] has an essay titled 'Kavanaugh Takes a Shot at Apple, and Big Tech Should Take Note; The Supreme Court is more open to antitrust litigation if the newest justice is willing to join liberals on this issue[48].' Posted at 4:23 PM [49] by Howard Bashman[50] 'Supreme Court Justice Gascon releases a statement on his health after his disappearance': Sean Fine of The Toronto Globe and Mail has this report[51]. Tonda MacCharles of The Toronto Star reports that 'Supreme Court justice says he had panic attack before going missing[52].' Peter Zimonjic of CBC News reports that 'Supreme Court Justice Gascon attributes disappearance to depression, anxiety[53].' And The Canadian Press has a report headlined 'Clement Gascon, high court justice who went missing, says he had panic attack; Gascon, who has already announced plans to retire, says he has long dealt with depression and anxiety[54].' Yesterday, the Supreme Court of Canada[55] issued this news release[56] on the matter. Posted at 4:08 PM [57] by Howard Bashman[58] 'A few thoughts on en banc oral argument: splitting time, the Soliloquy Rule, and flip flops somehow.' Matthew Stiegler has this post[59] at his 'CA3blog.' Posted at 4:00 PM [60] by Howard Bashman[61] 'Ask the author: 'So Long, Earl.'' At 'SCOTUSblog,' Andrew Hamm has this interview[62] with Michael Bobelian, author of 'Battle for the Marble Palace: Abe Fortas, Earl Warren, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, and the Forging of the Modern Supreme Court[63].' Posted at 1:57 PM [64] by Howard Bashman[65] 'Justice Department says FDA 'lacks jurisdiction' over death-penalty drugs': Laurie McGinley and Mark Berman of The Washington Post have this report[66]. And in today's edition of The New York Times, Charlie Savage has an article headlined 'Justice Dept. Stops F.D.A. From Regulating Death-Penalty Drugs[67].' Posted at 12:45 PM [68] by Howard Bashman[69] 'New witness list filed in Dan Markel murder case': Julie Montanaro of CBS affiliate WCTV Eyewitness News in Tallahassee has this report[70]. Posted at 12:05 PM [71] by Howard Bashman[72] 'Acknowledging His Own Misconduct: Most professors found to have violated Title IX policies don't share it with the world; This one did, as he resigned.' Colleen Flaherty of Inside Higher Ed has this report[73]. Posted at 12:02 PM [74] by Howard Bashman[75] 'Opinion analysis: Hyatt fulfills expectations in a surprising way.' Richard M. Re has this guest post[76] at 'SCOTUSblog.' Posted at 11:55 AM [77] by Howard Bashman[78] 'Experience in the Courtroom, Strong Role Models Give Grad Her Start; Women Role Models Helped Kendall Burchard '19 Along the Path': Eric Williamson of the University of Virginia School of Law has this report[79]. Posted at 11:50 AM [80] by Howard Bashman[81] 'An initial look at Peter Phipps, Trump's next Third Circuit nominee': Matthew Stiegler has this post[82] at his 'CA3blog.' Posted at 8:40 AM [83] by Howard Bashman[84] 'Court Says FEC Deadlocks Need No Second-Guessing By Judges': Kenneth P. Doyle of Bloomberg Law has this report[85] (subscription required for full access). And at his 'Election Law Blog,' Rick Hasen has a post titled 'DC Circuit Denies En Banc Consideration in Crew v. FEC Case, Essentially Giving Republican Commissioners Unfettered Ability to Block All Campaign Finance Enforcement Matters with No Judicial Review of the Decision[86].' You can access yesterday's order of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit[87] denying rehearing en banc, and the opinions concurring in and dissenting from that denial, at this link[88]. Posted at 8:34 AM [89] by Howard Bashman[90] 'I write separately to express my continued opposition to the use of conduct for which a defendant was acquitted to increase the length of that person's sentence.' So wrote D.C. Circuit[91] Judge Patricia A. Millett[92] in a concurring opinion[93] yesterday issued in an appeal involving a noteworthy criminal defendant[94]. urn:contentItem:5R5S-H6F1-JBHT-D362-00000-00Alabama Special Election; Terror in New York; Sexual Misconduct Allegations; Amex Dropping Signatures; Netflix Watching You; Ex-NFL Players2017-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisAlabama Special Election; Terror in New York; Sexual Misconduct Allegations; Amex Dropping Signatures; Netflix Watching You; Ex-NFL PlayersLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday December 12th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The race is on in Alabama, polls open one hour from now. Voters are deciding between Republican Roy Moore and Democrat Doug Jones in the highly-contested special election for the senate. The very latest as each candidate makes a last-ditch effort to drum up support.

Terrorism in New York -- authorities are searching for answers this morning while Homeland Security reveals the Bangladeshi man suspected of detonating a pipe bomb near New York City's port authority bus terminal entered the United States through so-called chain migration.

The White House responded to the news saying that it would not have happened under President Trump's immigration policy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: This attack underscores the need for Congress to work with the President on immigration reforms that enhance our national security and public safety. The President is certainly concerned that Congress, particularly Democrats, have failed to take action.

Specifically the President's policy has called for an end to chain migration and if that had been in place, that would have prevented this individual from coming to the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got the very latest this morning from the scene coming up.

Markets are mixed today. Futures indicating a higher opening for the Dow Industrials, up about 25 points right here. S&P 500 also up 1 point. And Nasdaq however is flat, negative by a point.

In Europe this morning, the major indices are higher across the board. The FT 100 up a fraction. CAC 40 and the -- the CAC 40 is up a quarter of a percent. And the DAX index also up a fraction.

In Asia overnight, markets were lower across the board, by the way, on the heels of another record setter yesterday on Wall Street. Shanghai composite down one and a quarter percent.

Several former NFL stars hit with sexual misconduct allegations. The details as they are suspended from the NFL network.

And American Express says put the pen away -- why they are no longer requiring signatures for purchases.

Plus users turning on Netflix as the streaming site reveals its top-watched shows. It also puts viewers on Blast for their binge-watching habits. The tweet that's sparking privacy concerns -- coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" global economics editor Jon Hilsenrath; and Beyond Sport global ambassador, Fox News contributor John Layfield. Great to see you.

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It's great to be here.

JON HILSENRATH, GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good to be here with you.

HILSENRATH: Bitcoin -- that's the --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You're loving the bitcoin.

HILSENRATH: Yes, yes. We can't stop talking about it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well --

HILSENRATH: $16,000.

BARTIROMO: I'm more into talking about the tax plan because I'm wondering if this new provision in the Senate plan is going to create a selloff in the stock market by year-end -- Jon.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, I think there's a real problem with year-end tax planning right now because they're going to have a bill done in the next week and a half and anyone who wants to position their 2017 taxes for year-end, they don't know -- they are going to have a week to respond and they're going to still be figuring out what's inside the bill. There just not a lot of time to work with here.

BARTIROMO: And there is this story in the Journal, right -- Dagen, about the small investment community basically taking a look at this idea that you have to sell your big winners first.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Top story in the Journal -- stock investors face a new tax hit (ph). This is the number one story that the Journal is reporting.

LAYFIELD: Only Congress could turn simple math into calculus. It was a very simple tax policy and they --

BARTIROMO: It was simple. What the heck happened?

HILSENRATH: This provision that Dagen is talking about -- it's about first in-first out, they only get $2 billion out of that over ten years. It's not clear why they need to do that when it's going to anger so many people.

BARTIROMO: Well, we're going to talk about that this morning.

And joining the conversation is AOL co-founder, Revolution chairman Steve Case is here. New York Congressman Pete King also joining the conversation; and the inspiration of the acclaimed 2015 movie "Joy", the self-made millionaire, inventor of the Miracle Mop Joy Mangano is with us this morning. You don't want to miss that. We will find out her entrepreneurial story.

But first our top story this hour. The Alabama polls open one hour from now. Republican candidate Roy Moore, Democratic candidate Doug Jones campaigned in Alabama yesterday in a last-ditch effort to gain support.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JUDGE ROY MOORE (R), ALABAMA SENATE CANDIDATE: We are up our neck in alligators. We are up to neck in people that don't want change in Washington, D.C. They want to keep it the same, keep their power, keep their prestige and keep their position. And we've got to change that.

DOUG JONES (D), ALABAMA SENATE CANDIDATE: I'm not going to worry about the fact that Roy Moore has been kicked out of office twice. I'm not going to worry about the fact that he took money from a charity. And, you know what, I believe those women in Etowah County but you know what, my party is more important.

I am going to tell you, folks, it is time. And I think we are going to see it tomorrow.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now from Washington is the "Daily Caller" editor in chief Christopher Bedford. Christopher -- good to see you. Thanks for joining us this morning.

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, EDITOR IN CHIEF, "DAILY CALLER": Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: First topic -- your take on the Alabama Senate election?

BEDFORD: I think it's pretty hard to see Roy Moore not winning this election today despite the fact he's had all these allegations that have come out against him but voters there support him. And you know, maybe if the Democrats run a more conservative Democrat as opposed to someone who is extremely liberal on abortion, on health care, on taxes -- they might have had more of a fighting chance to unseat a Republican in this race. But it's really hard to see it.

And they are trying, though. They are sending Barack Obama down. They're sending the former first lady down. They're sending Cory Booker down. A lot of Democratic all-stars are going to try and change this but right now the polls are generally, with a few outliers, looking like Roy Moore is going to win.

BARTIROMO: Roy Moore -- I thought that it looked like Doug Jones was 10 points ahead according to a Fox News poll.

BEDFORD: I know, the Fox News poll was an interesting blast and everyone has been talking about it for the last 24 hours.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BEDFORD: But if you look at the Real Clear Politics average of all the polls, Roy is still holding up a few points ahead. And that's the word I'm getting on the ground and it's going to be wild if Fox News turns out to be the outlier that makes everyone else look foolish in this crazy polling world we have these days.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

LAYFIELD: Christopher -- is part of this sentiment, you know, forget the veracity of the claim, we don't have time to figure out if these allegations are true. Is part of this simply that you've seen in elections in the western hemisphere like with Theresa May, with Brexit, with President Trump -- people just don't like to be told what to do. And is that part of what's going on in Alabama?

BEDFORD: I think that's true. The people in Alabama have really largely been dismissed and attacked repeatedly by national news media and by national political figures who sort of called them stupid or said how could you support this bigot. Or how could you support this molester?

And also places like the "Washington Post" and CNN have lost a lot of their capital with Republican voters from years and years of unfair coverage even just this last week of three massive retractions in the news. Republican voters and conservatives are less likely to believe them than ever.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

MCDOWELL: Well, Christopher -- you're saying though if it wasn't the "Washington Post" that broke the story about these women and their allegations, that if it was some other publication who had done it, that it would somehow have changed the way that people would vote in that state?

BEDFORD: It's possible. You hear it repeatedly -- repeatedly, consider the source. I don't think that's necessarily always fair because the source of these allegations are different women in the state of Alabama, but since it's come out and especially after decades of not having come out while Roy Moore has been a very public figure in Alabama, then the national news media descends on the state, shows more interest in it than it has since the 60s and they come out with all these allegations from people and it comes from a source that's less trusted in the state, that definitely hurt it.

BARTIROMO: Let me move on to what happened yesterday in New York. New York City is reeling from a bombing in Times Square. The White House responded to suspicion that the Bangladeshi suspect currently in custody entered through U.S. chain migration.

This comes as Reuters is reporting that Bangladeshi police are questioning the suspect's wife. Christopher -- what's your take on this?

BEDFORD: And it's not just chain migration, it's Donald Trump's other bogeyman -- it's the diversity lottery. The person who came in, came in through a diversity lottery, a relative of his. And this suspect here, very likely suspect, since the pipe bomb went off in his pocket, was the fourth removed family member to be able to -- the most distant removed family member to be able to come through on this diversity lottery and then through chain migration.

These kind of things, this is actually maybe almost a good thing for the Republicans and for Donald Trump because it's the kind of terror attack where no one was hurt except for the suspect. We don't have a lose of life. You have someone who is clearly connected to ISIS and it makes too, the President's point for him.

It's going to be difficult to defend this. There are a lot of people on the left that have been saying migration has got nothing to do with this. Of course, it's got something to do with it, that's why he was here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You would think so but you're not really hearing the mainstream media connect the dots on that one.

BEDFORD: Not yet.

BARTIROMO: No, not yet.

Let me ask you about this dossier scandal because this is really something that the "Daily Caller" has been doing such a good job on. A senior Justice Department official demoted for concealing meetings with the men behind the anti-rump dossier, has personal ties to Fusion GPS.

This is a Fox News exclusive. His wife worked for Fusion GPS in 2016 during the election. Every day we get another point of conflict of interest around this Russia probe, around Fusion GPS and Hillary Clinton. Your take on this.

BEDFORD: I wanted to withhold judgment for a while when it first came out that a lot of these people at a point had donated to Democrats, a lot of these investigators. Because you want to say that these people are going to do their jobs. They're investigators. They're professionals.

But every single day we are seeing more and more problems. Or actually it's actually -- Republicans are not getting answers in Congress when they are asking the FBI, why weren't we told about this person with these connections? why do we have to find about this from the news media? Why is the FBI not reporting back to us about all of these conflict of interests, really blatant ones.

I mean this guy was married to somebody at Fusion GPS. That's a pretty close connection right there. And I think these kinds of things are going to lead for a call for another special investigator and possibly Jeff Sessions to appoint one to keep an eye on the investigators.

BARTIROMO: It's not happening, though. That's the thing.

I mean people want to see justice and that's -- what you're saying is still not happening. And there have been subpoenas out for information -- haven't there, Dagen -- from Congress. There have been subpoenas out to actually get information and there's stonewalling going on for years.

MCDOWELL: I don't know how do you -- how much taxpayer money though, Chris, is it going to take to basically -- to use the President's phrase -- drain the swamp? The more you find out about what goes to Washington, the more disgusted the average American is about everybody in bed with everyone -- you know, everybody in bed together.

There's back scratching and there's never any justice for the average person. There's never any conclusion that is satisfying to the taxpayer who are footing these bills.

BEDFORD: One of the most annoying things you'll find about Washington, D.C. is as soon as you go out and you go out for dinner or go out for a drink, one of the first things someone asks you is so what do you do.

You don't get that in other cities because Washington, D.C. is so interconnected, everyone is somehow working with everyone and they have an interest in that. The swamp is deeply connected with each other. These people have an active interest in keeping outsiders out of it.

And Donald Trump is actually causing massive disruption with these people. It's causing chaos. I mean all my neighbors' sons right now, they have all this (INAUDIBLE) signaling about how they stand up and they were just against Trump and let no man put hate in your heart.

Everyone around this city is resisting him. And it's going to take a lot of effort. It's going to take a few years. And I think we're going to see a see a couple of fires, brush fires along the way before anything gets done on the swamp.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So just to be clear. Fusion GPS basically came up with this dossier which was never verified and was a bunch garbage and that was one of the justifications for wiretapping Donald Trump.

BEDFORD: That's what we're trying to figure out if that was one of the justifications. And right now what we are certain of is that it was full of garbage that has caused massive disruption in the news media and then it likely influenced the FBI and Department of Justice to move in on the Trump administration.

BARTIROMO: What we're seeing on that screen is what you're seeing in your glasses?

TRAVERS: That's correct. That's correct. So you can imagine so many applications where this can become a valuable tool.

BARTIROMO: you made the analogy earlier, if you're on a plane, on your -- unloading the baggage from a plane.

TRAVERS: Yes. We worked with folks like SATS at Changi Airport and they have the gate folks wearing these glasses. The pallet comes by, on the side of pallet, a few barcode, barcode kind of a thing. Through these glasses you see all of the information about where that pallet goes on a plane. What section of the plane it belongs in.

If it doesn't belong on that plane, they will have a red marker on the outside of it and just like this building that's not real or marker is not real, but digitally, they can put it in remove it ad at the same time --

BARTIROMO: They know where the baggage goes on the plane.

TRAVERS: They can turn around a plane in one half, the amount of time compared to how they do it today.

BARTIROMO: That's very cool. So Vuzix recently entered into a supply agreement with Toshiba. Tell us about that.

TRAVERS: I can tell you a little bit about that.

BARTIROMO: Come on.

TRAVERS: Well, it's very exciting for me, actually. It's one of the largest, probably orders that smart glasses have seen, quite frankly. Toshiba is a major player in the laptop space. They're coming out with a line of products that are wearable, etch-oriented and they're buying smart glasses from Vuzix.

BARTIROMO: Really? Cool stuff.

TRAVERS: We learn a lot more about that here. It's a multimillion-dollar contract for Vuzix and sometime here in the first quarter, Toshiba will be sharing a lot more. What is the world and 3D?

BARTIROMO: I feel that if you don't have augmented reality or A.I. or some sort, you're going to be left behind, because every industry is using it at this point.

TRAVERS: We have companies getting -- doing things 500 percent ROI, It's really hard to ignore.

BARTIROMO: Cool stuff. Paul, thank you so much.

TRAVERS: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, Paul from Vuzix there.

Still ahead, inventing inspiration. We will talk to a self-made Joy Mangano about her widely popular home shopping network empire.

And the acclaimed 2015 movie loosely based on her life, starring Jennifer Lawrence. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

END

urn:contentItem:5R5S-H6F1-JBHT-D36F-00000-00Alabama Special Election; Terror in New York; Sexual Misconduct Allegations; Amex Dropping Signatures; Netflix Watching You; Ex-NFL Players2017-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisAlabama Special Election; Terror in New York; Sexual Misconduct Allegations; Amex Dropping Signatures; Netflix Watching You; Ex-NFL PlayersLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday December 12th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The race is on in Alabama, polls open one hour from now. Voters are deciding between Republican Roy Moore and Democrat Doug Jones in the highly-contested special election for the senate. The very latest as each candidate makes a last-ditch effort to drum up support.

Terrorism in New York -- authorities are searching for answers this morning while Homeland Security reveals the Bangladeshi man suspected of detonating a pipe bomb near New York City's port authority bus terminal entered the United States through so-called chain migration.

The White House responded to the news saying that it would not have happened under President Trump's immigration policy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: This attack underscores the need for Congress to work with the President on immigration reforms that enhance our national security and public safety. The President is certainly concerned that Congress, particularly Democrats, have failed to take action.

Specifically the President's policy has called for an end to chain migration and if that had been in place, that would have prevented this individual from coming to the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got the very latest this morning from the scene coming up.

Markets are mixed today. Futures indicating a higher opening for the Dow Industrials, up about 25 points right here. S&P 500 also up 1 point. And Nasdaq however is flat, negative by a point.

In Europe this morning, the major indices are higher across the board. The FT 100 up a fraction. CAC 40 and the -- the CAC 40 is up a quarter of a percent. And the DAX index also up a fraction.

In Asia overnight, markets were lower across the board, by the way, on the heels of another record setter yesterday on Wall Street. Shanghai composite down one and a quarter percent.

Several former NFL stars hit with sexual misconduct allegations. The details as they are suspended from the NFL network.

And American Express says put the pen away -- why they are no longer requiring signatures for purchases.

Plus users turning on Netflix as the streaming site reveals its top-watched shows. It also puts viewers on Blast for their binge-watching habits. The tweet that's sparking privacy concerns -- coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" global economics editor Jon Hilsenrath; and Beyond Sport global ambassador, Fox News contributor John Layfield. Great to see you.

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It's great to be here.

JON HILSENRATH, GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good to be here with you.

HILSENRATH: Bitcoin -- that's the --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You're loving the bitcoin.

HILSENRATH: Yes, yes. We can't stop talking about it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well --

HILSENRATH: $16,000.

BARTIROMO: I'm more into talking about the tax plan because I'm wondering if this new provision in the Senate plan is going to create a selloff in the stock market by year-end -- Jon.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, I think there's a real problem with year-end tax planning right now because they're going to have a bill done in the next week and a half and anyone who wants to position their 2017 taxes for year-end, they don't know -- they are going to have a week to respond and they're going to still be figuring out what's inside the bill. There just not a lot of time to work with here.

BARTIROMO: And there is this story in the Journal, right -- Dagen, about the small investment community basically taking a look at this idea that you have to sell your big winners first.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Top story in the Journal -- stock investors face a new tax hit (ph). This is the number one story that the Journal is reporting.

LAYFIELD: Only Congress could turn simple math into calculus. It was a very simple tax policy and they --

BARTIROMO: It was simple. What the heck happened?

HILSENRATH: This provision that Dagen is talking about -- it's about first in-first out, they only get $2 billion out of that over ten years. It's not clear why they need to do that when it's going to anger so many people.

BARTIROMO: Well, we're going to talk about that this morning.

And joining the conversation is AOL co-founder, Revolution chairman Steve Case is here. New York Congressman Pete King also joining the conversation; and the inspiration of the acclaimed 2015 movie "Joy", the self-made millionaire, inventor of the Miracle Mop Joy Mangano is with us this morning. You don't want to miss that. We will find out her entrepreneurial story.

But first our top story this hour. The Alabama polls open one hour from now. Republican candidate Roy Moore, Democratic candidate Doug Jones campaigned in Alabama yesterday in a last-ditch effort to gain support.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JUDGE ROY MOORE (R), ALABAMA SENATE CANDIDATE: We are up our neck in alligators. We are up to neck in people that don't want change in Washington, D.C. They want to keep it the same, keep their power, keep their prestige and keep their position. And we've got to change that.

DOUG JONES (D), ALABAMA SENATE CANDIDATE: I'm not going to worry about the fact that Roy Moore has been kicked out of office twice. I'm not going to worry about the fact that he took money from a charity. And, you know what, I believe those women in Etowah County but you know what, my party is more important.

I am going to tell you, folks, it is time. And I think we are going to see it tomorrow.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now from Washington is the "Daily Caller" editor in chief Christopher Bedford. Christopher -- good to see you. Thanks for joining us this morning.

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, EDITOR IN CHIEF, "DAILY CALLER": Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: First topic -- your take on the Alabama Senate election?

BEDFORD: I think it's pretty hard to see Roy Moore not winning this election today despite the fact he's had all these allegations that have come out against him but voters there support him. And you know, maybe if the Democrats run a more conservative Democrat as opposed to someone who is extremely liberal on abortion, on health care, on taxes -- they might have had more of a fighting chance to unseat a Republican in this race. But it's really hard to see it.

And they are trying, though. They are sending Barack Obama down. They're sending the former first lady down. They're sending Cory Booker down. A lot of Democratic all-stars are going to try and change this but right now the polls are generally, with a few outliers, looking like Roy Moore is going to win.

BARTIROMO: Roy Moore -- I thought that it looked like Doug Jones was 10 points ahead according to a Fox News poll.

BEDFORD: I know, the Fox News poll was an interesting blast and everyone has been talking about it for the last 24 hours.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BEDFORD: But if you look at the Real Clear Politics average of all the polls, Roy is still holding up a few points ahead. And that's the word I'm getting on the ground and it's going to be wild if Fox News turns out to be the outlier that makes everyone else look foolish in this crazy polling world we have these days.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

LAYFIELD: Christopher -- is part of this sentiment, you know, forget the veracity of the claim, we don't have time to figure out if these allegations are true. Is part of this simply that you've seen in elections in the western hemisphere like with Theresa May, with Brexit, with President Trump -- people just don't like to be told what to do. And is that part of what's going on in Alabama?

BEDFORD: I think that's true. The people in Alabama have really largely been dismissed and attacked repeatedly by national news media and by national political figures who sort of called them stupid or said how could you support this bigot. Or how could you support this molester?

And also places like the "Washington Post" and CNN have lost a lot of their capital with Republican voters from years and years of unfair coverage even just this last week of three massive retractions in the news. Republican voters and conservatives are less likely to believe them than ever.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

MCDOWELL: Well, Christopher -- you're saying though if it wasn't the "Washington Post" that broke the story about these women and their allegations, that if it was some other publication who had done it, that it would somehow have changed the way that people would vote in that state?

BEDFORD: It's possible. You hear it repeatedly -- repeatedly, consider the source. I don't think that's necessarily always fair because the source of these allegations are different women in the state of Alabama, but since it's come out and especially after decades of not having come out while Roy Moore has been a very public figure in Alabama, then the national news media descends on the state, shows more interest in it than it has since the 60s and they come out with all these allegations from people and it comes from a source that's less trusted in the state, that definitely hurt it.

BARTIROMO: Let me move on to what happened yesterday in New York. New York City is reeling from a bombing in Times Square. The White House responded to suspicion that the Bangladeshi suspect currently in custody entered through U.S. chain migration.

This comes as Reuters is reporting that Bangladeshi police are questioning the suspect's wife. Christopher -- what's your take on this?

BEDFORD: And it's not just chain migration, it's Donald Trump's other bogeyman -- it's the diversity lottery. The person who came in, came in through a diversity lottery, a relative of his. And this suspect here, very likely suspect, since the pipe bomb went off in his pocket, was the fourth removed family member to be able to -- the most distant removed family member to be able to come through on this diversity lottery and then through chain migration.

These kind of things, this is actually maybe almost a good thing for the Republicans and for Donald Trump because it's the kind of terror attack where no one was hurt except for the suspect. We don't have a lose of life. You have someone who is clearly connected to ISIS and it makes too, the President's point for him.

It's going to be difficult to defend this. There are a lot of people on the left that have been saying migration has got nothing to do with this. Of course, it's got something to do with it, that's why he was here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You would think so but you're not really hearing the mainstream media connect the dots on that one.

BEDFORD: Not yet.

BARTIROMO: No, not yet.

Let me ask you about this dossier scandal because this is really something that the "Daily Caller" has been doing such a good job on. A senior Justice Department official demoted for concealing meetings with the men behind the anti-rump dossier, has personal ties to Fusion GPS.

This is a Fox News exclusive. His wife worked for Fusion GPS in 2016 during the election. Every day we get another point of conflict of interest around this Russia probe, around Fusion GPS and Hillary Clinton. Your take on this.

BEDFORD: I wanted to withhold judgment for a while when it first came out that a lot of these people at a point had donated to Democrats, a lot of these investigators. Because you want to say that these people are going to do their jobs. They're investigators. They're professionals.

But every single day we are seeing more and more problems. Or actually it's actually -- Republicans are not getting answers in Congress when they are asking the FBI, why weren't we told about this person with these connections? why do we have to find about this from the news media? Why is the FBI not reporting back to us about all of these conflict of interests, really blatant ones.

I mean this guy was married to somebody at Fusion GPS. That's a pretty close connection right there. And I think these kinds of things are going to lead for a call for another special investigator and possibly Jeff Sessions to appoint one to keep an eye on the investigators.

BARTIROMO: It's not happening, though. That's the thing.

I mean people want to see justice and that's -- what you're saying is still not happening. And there have been subpoenas out for information -- haven't there, Dagen -- from Congress. There have been subpoenas out to actually get information and there's stonewalling going on for years.

MCDOWELL: I don't know how do you -- how much taxpayer money though, Chris, is it going to take to basically -- to use the President's phrase -- drain the swamp? The more you find out about what goes to Washington, the more disgusted the average American is about everybody in bed with everyone -- you know, everybody in bed together.

There's back scratching and there's never any justice for the average person. There's never any conclusion that is satisfying to the taxpayer who are footing these bills.

BEDFORD: One of the most annoying things you'll find about Washington, D.C. is as soon as you go out and you go out for dinner or go out for a drink, one of the first things someone asks you is so what do you do.

You don't get that in other cities because Washington, D.C. is so interconnected, everyone is somehow working with everyone and they have an interest in that. The swamp is deeply connected with each other. These people have an active interest in keeping outsiders out of it.

And Donald Trump is actually causing massive disruption with these people. It's causing chaos. I mean all my neighbors' sons right now, they have all this (INAUDIBLE) signaling about how they stand up and they were just against Trump and let no man put hate in your heart.

Everyone around this city is resisting him. And it's going to take a lot of effort. It's going to take a few years. And I think we're going to see a see a couple of fires, brush fires along the way before anything gets done on the swamp.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So just to be clear. Fusion GPS basically came up with this dossier which was never verified and was a bunch garbage and that was one of the justifications for wiretapping Donald Trump.

BEDFORD: That's what we're trying to figure out if that was one of the justifications. And right now what we are certain of is that it was full of garbage that has caused massive disruption in the news media and then it likely influenced the FBI and Department of Justice to move in on the Trump administration.

And now we are finding out the FBI agents were intimately connected to it. That does not look good for Mueller or his probe.

MCDOWELL: Well, one thing we do know is that Christopher Steele, the former British intelligence agent who was paid by Fusion GPS and the Democrats to work with Russians to put together this dossier that the FBI was talking to him about putting him on the payroll. We know that. That is a fact and that has been proven.

So, again, to Christopher's point -- is it going to be up to Bob Mueller and his conflicted team? I mean there are more conflict that we haven't even covered today. Is it going to fall to him to investigate the FBI which he ran for 12 years?

BARTIROMO: How is he going to investigate the FBI, he ran it?

MCDOWELL: And Jim Comey, his very close friend -- is it going to be up to him and his team to investigate what went on with this dossier. And to Chris' point, you've got to have somebody else doing it.

BARTIROMO: Well, we will see. If we actually do get the special prosecutor, another special prosecutor looking at it. I don't know. I don't have a high expectation of that -- Chris. But we'll see.

I want to get your take on this breaking news. President Trump is tweeting this morning. Here is what he said. "Despite thousands of hours wasted and many millions of dollars spent the Democrats have been unable to show any collusion with Russia. So now they are moving on to the false accusations and fabricated stories of women who I don't know and/or have never met. Fake news."

Wow, the President coming up this morning, talking about the allegations from the women who are trying to get a congressional investigation going about inappropriate behavior, sexual inappropriate behavior. Chris -- your thoughts?

BEDFORD: It was wild to watch the White House press conference yesterday. It was almost like it was coordinated amongst a blob of people who think all the same. We get a terror attack in New York. We had tax reform coming down. We've got a special election tomorrow in Alabama.

And almost every one in the press wanted to talk about -- all they wanted to talk about was these accusations. The President so far has denied them. Sarah Huckabee Sanders up there saying I speak for the President, the President flat out denies this.

It does not mean it's not going to stop and when you see Democrats so brutally cleaning out their own house of anyone who has been accused of any kind of sexual misconduct, I see them as doing that to try and set themselves up to retake the moral high ground and go hard after President Trump over these accusations.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, Megyn Kelly had them on her show and then they did a press conference after that. You're right. Christopher -- thank you.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We will see you soon, sir. Christopher Bedford there.

Still ahead -- when it comes to a pen, you can leave home without it. Why American Express is ditching its signature requirements.

And then binge in the New Year -- Netflix revealing the most streamed shows of 2017. The surprising series that took the top spot. Plus the new privacy concerns sparked by a tweet from the streaming giant.

Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

When we told you yesterday about the outpouring of support for Tennessee middle-schooler who went viral talking about bullying, now there are questions about his mother's motives for posting that video.

Cheryl Casone with the details right now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes -- Maria.

So there were more than 22 million hits on Kimberly Jones' heartbreaking footage of her son Keaton describing being called "ugly" at a school. Someone even launched a go fund me campaign that raised more than $58,000. But as attention spread so did interest in her.

She started her own go fund me page actually and then she slammed the original fundraiser and they are questioning whether she's just trying to make a quick buck off of her son.

Reports also began to emerge that she had posted multiple images of confederate flags on her Facebook account. Jones has since made her Facebook page private.

Well, American Express trying to stay competitive. Starting next April, the company will no longer require a signature regardless of the amount you're spending. Right now you have to sign for any purchase over $50. Of course, the latest credit cards have a computer chip for additional fraud protection. No signature required if you buy something online or on your phone. But it's been a strong year for American Express. The stock is actually up more than 30 percent.

Well, streamers that saw Netflix's tweet over the weekend were a little creeped-out with how much the company seems to know about their viewing habits. Netflix tweeted this, "To the 53 people who watched a Christmas Prince every day for the past 18 days who hurt you question?" Well, the tweet got a lot of laughs. It was re-tweeted over 100,000 times but also some backlash because viewers are thinking, hey, wait a minute, do I have any privacy with you, maybe I don't.

All right, but all that viewership data proving useful to Netflix. The company has come up with its official "shows we devoured" list which means a series was viewed more than two hours per day.

The list is surprisingly topped by -- this is interesting -- "The True Crime" spoof "American Vandal". Followed by the Brazilian series "3 Percent; the controversial "13 Reasons Why", "Anne with an E" and "Riverdale". The most popular streaming day in 2017 was actually New Year's Day. Netflix stock up sharply so far this year.

And no, Dagen -- "Narcos" wasn't on that list or "The Crown".

BARTIROMO: Neither was "House of Cards".

CASONE: I don't know what to say.

BARTIROMO: Have you seen any of those shows on that list -- Cheryl?

CASONE: No.

BARTIROMO: Neither have I.

MCDOWELL: I haven't either.

CASONE: What's wrong with me?

BARTIROMO: I haven't seen any of those shows.

CASONE: Am I a nerd?

BARTIROMO: How is that possible?

MCDOWELL: I don't know. Something is deeply wrong with me. I did. I'm almost done --

LAYFIELD: I have not seen any of it --

BARTIROMO: Jon? What are these shows?

MCDOWELL: I'm almost done with the second season of "The Crown".

BARTIROMO: How is it?

As a result, Disney is basically saying they're going to pull back from Netflix and do their own direct to consumer offering. Amazon willing to pay out billions and billions of dollars for original content, is that where this is going? A lot of things around Ag tech, Louisville and St. Louis around Ag tech, farming.

So it now become so much more central in terms of our everyday lives. Had such a big impact on our economy. It's not surprising that there's more of a focus on the role of big tech if you will. And do I think Silicon Valley needs to be careful.

CASE: Well, I think it's exciting one though, but take this in their core technologies around block chain. Now, here's a little bit of a mania particularly on the trading side around bitcoin and ICOs, things like that.

I saw even yesterday, as he stepped in to stop ICO, an initial coin offering that was happening and this idea that you can raise capital in an unregulated way which has happened recently. I don't think that is sustainable.
