urn:contentItem:5R5D-6D41-JB20-G3TR-00000-00Alabama Special Election; Terror in New York; Sexual Misconduct Allegations; Amex Dropping Signatures; Netflix Watching You; Ex-NFL Players Benched; Mergers Reshaping Media; Case on Merger Mania; Case on Net Neutrality; Scouting for New Flavors; San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee Dead at 65; Feminism Word of the Year2017-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTJon Hilsenrath, Christopher Bedford, Steve Case, Paul TraversNEWSFinancial121202cb.231Alabama Special Election; Terror in New York; Sexual Misconduct Allegations; Amex Dropping Signatures; NetflixWatching You; Ex-NFL Players Benched; Mergers Reshaping Media; Case on Merger Mania; Case on Net Neutrality; Scouting for New Flavors; San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee Dead at 65; Feminism Word of the YearMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, John Layfield, Cheryl Casone, Jared Max

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday December 12th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

The race is on in Alabama, polls open one hour from now. Voters are deciding between Republican Roy Moore and Democrat Doug Jones in the highly-contested special election for the senate. The very latest as each candidate makes a last-ditch effort to drum up support.

Terrorism in New York -- authorities are searching for answers this morning while Homeland Security reveals the Bangladeshi man suspected of detonating a pipe bomb near New York City's port authority bus terminal entered the United States through so-called chain migration.

The White House responded to the news saying that it would not have happened under President Trump's immigration policy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: This attack underscores the need for Congress to work with the President on immigration reforms that enhance our national security and public safety. The President is certainly concerned that Congress, particularly Democrats, have failed to take action.

Specifically the President's policy has called for an end to chain migration and if that had been in place, that would have prevented this individual from coming to the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We've got the very latest this morning from the scene coming up.

Markets are mixed today. Futures indicating a higher opening for the Dow Industrials, up about 25 points right here. S&P 500 also up 1 point. And Nasdaq however is flat, negative by a point.

In Europe this morning, the major indices are higher across the board. The FT 100 up a fraction. CAC 40 and the -- the CAC 40 is up a quarter of a percent. And the DAX index also up a fraction.

In Asia overnight, markets were lower across the board, by the way, on the heels of another record setter yesterday on Wall Street. Shanghai composite down one and a quarter percent.

Several former NFL stars hit with sexual misconduct allegations. The details as they are suspended from the NFL network.

And American Express says put the pen away -- why they are no longer requiring signatures for purchases.

Plus users turning on Netflixas the streaming site reveals its top-watched shows. It also puts viewers on Blast for their binge-watching habits. The tweet that's sparking privacy concerns -- coming up.

All those stories coming up this morning. And joining me to break it all down: Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the "Wall Street Journal's" global economics editor Jon Hilsenrath; and Beyond Sport global ambassador, Fox News contributor John Layfield. Great to see you.

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: It's great to be here.

JON HILSENRATH, GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good to be here with you.

HILSENRATH: Bitcoin -- that's the --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You're loving the bitcoin.

HILSENRATH: Yes, yes. We can't stop talking about it.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well --

HILSENRATH: $16,000.

BARTIROMO: I'm more into talking about the tax plan because I'm wondering if this new provision in the Senate plan is going to create a selloff in the stock market by year-end -- Jon.

HILSENRATH: Well, you know, I think there's a real problem with year-end tax planning right now because they're going to have a bill done in the next week and a half and anyone who wants to position their 2017 taxes for year-end, they don't know -- they are going to have a week to respond and they're going to still be figuring out what's inside the bill. There just not a lot of time to work with here.

BARTIROMO: And there is this story in the Journal, right -- Dagen, about the small investment community basically taking a look at this idea that you have to sell your big winners first.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Top story in the Journal -- stock investors face a new tax hit (ph). This is the number one story that the Journal is reporting.

LAYFIELD: Only Congress could turn simple math into calculus. It was a very simple tax policy and they --

BARTIROMO: It was simple. What the heck happened?

HILSENRATH: This provision that Dagen is talking about -- it's about first in-first out, they only get $2 billion out of that over ten years. It's not clear why they need to do that when it's going to anger so many people.

BARTIROMO: Well, we're going to talk about that this morning.

And joining the conversation is AOL co-founder, Revolution chairman Steve Case is here. New York Congressman Pete King also joining the conversation; and the inspiration of the acclaimed 2015 movie "Joy", the self-made millionaire, inventor of the Miracle Mop Joy Mangano is with us this morning. You don't want to miss that. We will find out her entrepreneurial story.

But first our top story this hour. The Alabama polls open one hour from now. Republican candidate Roy Moore, Democratic candidate Doug Jones campaigned in Alabama yesterday in a last-ditch effort to gain support.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JUDGE ROY MOORE (R), ALABAMA SENATE CANDIDATE: We are up our neck in alligators. We are up to neck in people that don't want change in Washington, D.C. They want to keep it the same, keep their power, keep their prestige and keep their position. And we've got to change that.

DOUG JONES (D), ALABAMA SENATE CANDIDATE: I'm not going to worry about the fact that Roy Moore has been kicked out of office twice. I'm not going to worry about the fact that he took money from a charity. And, you know what, I believe those women in Etowah County but you know what, my party is more important.

I am going to tell you, folks, it is time. And I think we are going to see it tomorrow.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now from Washington is the "Daily Caller" editor in chief Christopher Bedford. Christopher -- good to see you. Thanks for joining us this morning.

CHRISTOPHER BEDFORD, EDITOR IN CHIEF, "DAILY CALLER": Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: First topic -- your take on the Alabama Senate election?

BEDFORD: I think it's pretty hard to see Roy Moore not winning this election today despite the fact he's had all these allegations that have come out against him but voters there support him. And you know, maybe if the Democrats run a more conservative Democrat as opposed to someone who is extremely liberal on abortion, on health care, on taxes -- they might have had more of a fighting chance to unseat a Republican in this race. But it's really hard to see it.

And they are trying, though. They are sending Barack Obama down. They're sending the former first lady down. They're sending Cory Booker down. A lot of Democratic all-stars are going to try and change this but right now the polls are generally, with a few outliers, looking like Roy Moore is going to win.

BARTIROMO: Roy Moore -- I thought that it looked like Doug Jones was 10 points ahead according to a Fox News poll.

BEDFORD: I know, the Fox News poll was an interesting blast and everyone has been talking about it for the last 24 hours.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BEDFORD: But if you look at the Real Clear Politics average of all the polls, Roy is still holding up a few points ahead. And that's the word I'm getting on the ground and it's going to be wild if Fox News turns out to be the outlier that makes everyone else look foolish in this crazy polling world we have these days.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

LAYFIELD: Christopher -- is part of this sentiment, you know, forget the veracity of the claim, we don't have time to figure out if these allegations are true. Is part of this simply that you've seen in elections in the western hemisphere like with Theresa May, with Brexit, with President Trump -- people just don't like to be told what to do. And is that part of what's going on in Alabama?

BEDFORD: I think that's true. The people in Alabama have really largely been dismissed and attacked repeatedly by national news media and by national political figures who sort of called them stupid or said how could you support this bigot. Or how could you support this molester?

And also places like the "Washington Post" and CNN have lost a lot of their capital with Republican voters from years and years of unfair coverage even just this last week of three massive retractions in the news. Republican voters and conservatives are less likely to believe them than ever.

BARTIROMO: That's true.

MCDOWELL: Well, Christopher -- you're saying though if it wasn't the "Washington Post" that broke the story about these women and their allegations, that if it was some other publication who had done it, that it would somehow have changed the way that people would vote in that state?

BEDFORD: It's possible. You hear it repeatedly -- repeatedly, consider the source. I don't think that's necessarily always fair because the source of these allegations are different women in the state of Alabama, but since it's come out and especially after decades of not having come out while Roy Moore has been a very public figure in Alabama, then the national news media descends on the state, shows more interest in it than it has since the 60s and they come out with all these allegations from people and it comes from a source that's less trusted in the state, that definitely hurt it.

BARTIROMO: Let me move on to what happened yesterday in New York. New York City is reeling from a bombing in Times Square. The White House responded to suspicion that the Bangladeshi suspect currently in custody entered through U.S. chain migration.

This comes as Reuters is reporting that Bangladeshi police are questioning the suspect's wife. Christopher -- what's your take on this?

BEDFORD: And it's not just chain migration, it's Donald Trump's other bogeyman -- it's the diversity lottery. The person who came in, came in through a diversity lottery, a relative of his. And this suspect here, very likely suspect, since the pipe bomb went off in his pocket, was the fourth removed family member to be able to -- the most distant removed family member to be able to come through on this diversity lottery and then through chain migration.

These kind of things, this is actually maybe almost a good thing for the Republicans and for Donald Trump because it's the kind of terror attack where no one was hurt except for the suspect. We don't have a lose of life. You have someone who is clearly connected to ISIS and it makes too, the President's point for him.

It's going to be difficult to defend this. There are a lot of people on the left that have been saying migration has got nothing to do with this. Of course, it's got something to do with it, that's why he was here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You would think so but you're not really hearing the mainstream media connect the dots on that one.

BEDFORD: Not yet.

BARTIROMO: No, not yet.

Let me ask you about this dossier scandal because this is really something that the "Daily Caller" has been doing such a good job on. A senior Justice Department official demoted for concealing meetings with the men behind the anti-rump dossier, has personal ties to Fusion GPS.

This is a Fox News exclusive. His wife worked for Fusion GPS in 2016 during the election. Every day we get another point of conflict of interest around this Russia probe, around Fusion GPS and Hillary Clinton. Your take on this.

BEDFORD: I wanted to withhold judgment for a while when it first came out that a lot of these people at a point had donated to Democrats, a lot of these investigators. Because you want to say that these people are going to do their jobs. They're investigators. They're professionals.

But every single day we are seeing more and more problems. Or actually it's actually -- Republicans are not getting answers in Congress when they are asking the FBI, why weren't we told about this person with these connections? why do we have to find about this from the news media? Why is the FBI not reporting back to us about all of these conflict of interests, really blatant ones.

I mean this guy was married to somebody at Fusion GPS. That's a pretty close connection right there. And I think these kinds of things are going to lead for a call for another special investigator and possibly Jeff Sessions to appoint one to keep an eye on the investigators.

BARTIROMO: It's not happening, though. That's the thing.

I mean people want to see justice and that's -- what you're saying is still not happening. And there have been subpoenas out for information -- haven't there, Dagen -- from Congress. There have been subpoenas out to actually get information and there's stonewalling going on for years.

MCDOWELL: I don't know how do you -- how much taxpayer money though, Chris, is it going to take to basically -- to use the President's phrase -- drain the swamp? The more you find out about what goes to Washington, the more disgusted the average American is about everybody in bed with everyone -- you know, everybody in bed together.

There's back scratching and there's never any justice for the average person. There's never any conclusion that is satisfying to the taxpayer who are footing these bills.

BEDFORD: One of the most annoying things you'll find about Washington, D.C. is as soon as you go out and you go out for dinner or go out for a drink, one of the first things someone asks you is so what do you do.

You don't get that in other cities because Washington, D.C. is so interconnected, everyone is somehow working with everyone and they have an interest in that. The swamp is deeply connected with each other. These people have an active interest in keeping outsiders out of it.

And Donald Trump is actually causing massive disruption with these people. It's causing chaos. I mean all my neighbors' sons right now, they have all this (INAUDIBLE) signaling about how they stand up and they were just against Trump and let no man put hate in your heart.

Everyone around this city is resisting him. And it's going to take a lot of effort. It's going to take a few years. And I think we're going to see a see a couple of fires, brush fires along the way before anything gets done on the swamp.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So just to be clear. Fusion GPS basically came up with this dossier which was never verified and was a bunch garbage and that was one of the justifications for wiretapping Donald Trump.

BEDFORD: That's what we're trying to figure out if that was one of the justifications. And right now what we are certain of is that it was full of garbage that has caused massive disruption in the news media and then it likely influenced the FBI and Department of Justice to move in on the Trump administration.

And now we are finding out the FBI agents were intimately connected to it. That does not look good for Mueller or his probe.

MCDOWELL: Well, one thing we do know is that Christopher Steele, the former British intelligence agent who was paid by Fusion GPS and the Democrats to work with Russians to put together this dossier that the FBI was talking to him about putting him on the payroll. We know that. That is a fact and that has been proven.

So, again, to Christopher's point -- is it going to be up to Bob Mueller and his conflicted team? I mean there are more conflict that we haven't even covered today. Is it going to fall to him to investigate the FBI which he ran for 12 years?

BARTIROMO: How is he going to investigate the FBI, he ran it?

MCDOWELL: And Jim Comey, his very close friend -- is it going to be up to him and his team to investigate what went on with this dossier. And to Chris' point, you've got to have somebody else doing it.

BARTIROMO: Well, we will see. If we actually do get the special prosecutor, another special prosecutor looking at it. I don't know. I don't have a high expectation of that -- Chris. But we'll see.

I want to get your take on this breaking news. President Trump is tweeting this morning. Here is what he said. "Despite thousands of hours wasted and many millions of dollars spent the Democrats have been unable to show any collusion with Russia. So now they are moving on to the false accusations and fabricated stories of women who I don't know and/or have never met. Fake news."

Wow, the President coming up this morning, talking about the allegations from the women who are trying to get a congressional investigation going about inappropriate behavior, sexual inappropriate behavior. Chris -- your thoughts?

BEDFORD: It was wild to watch the White House press conference yesterday. It was almost like it was coordinated amongst a blob of people who think all the same. We get a terror attack in New York. We had tax reform coming down. We've got a special election tomorrow in Alabama.

And almost every one in the press wanted to talk about -- all they wanted to talk about was these accusations. The President so far has denied them. Sarah Huckabee Sanders up there saying I speak for the President, the President flat out denies this.

It does not mean it's not going to stop and when you see Democrats so brutally cleaning out their own house of anyone who has been accused of any kind of sexual misconduct, I see them as doing that to try and set themselves up to retake the moral high ground and go hard after President Trump over these accusations.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, Megyn Kelly had them on her show and then they did a press conference after that. You're right. Christopher -- thank you.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We will see you soon, sir. Christopher Bedford there.

Still ahead -- when it comes to a pen, you can leave home without it. Why American Express is ditching its signature requirements.

And then binge in the New Year -- Netflixrevealing the most streamed shows of 2017. The surprising series that took the top spot. Plus the new privacy concerns sparked by a tweet from the streaming giant.

Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

When we told you yesterday about the outpouring of support for Tennessee middle-schooler who went viral talking about bullying, now there are questions about his mother's motives for posting that video.

Cheryl Casone with the details right now -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes -- Maria.

So there were more than 22 million hits on Kimberly Jones' heartbreaking footage of her son Keaton describing being called "ugly" at a school. Someone even launched a go fund me campaign that raised more than $58,000. But as attention spread so did interest in her.

She started her own go fund me page actually and then she slammed the original fundraiser and they are questioning whether she's just trying to make a quick buck off of her son.

Reports also began to emerge that she had posted multiple images of confederate flags on her Facebook account. Jones has since made her Facebook page private.

Well, American Express trying to stay competitive. Starting next April, the company will no longer require a signature regardless of the amount you're spending. Right now you have to sign for any purchase over $50. Of course, the latest credit cards have a computer chip for additional fraud protection. No signature required if you buy something online or on your phone. But it's been a strong year for American Express. The stock is actually up more than 30 percent.

Well, streamers that saw Netflix's tweet over the weekend were a little creeped-out with how much the company seems to know about their viewing habits. Netflixtweeted this, "To the 53 people who watched a Christmas Prince every day for the past 18 days who hurt you question?" Well, the tweet got a lot of laughs. It was re-tweeted over 100,000 times but also some backlash because viewers are thinking, hey, wait a minute, do I have any privacy with you, maybe I don't.

All right, but all that viewership data proving useful to Netflix. The company has come up with its official "shows we devoured" list which means a series was viewed more than two hours per day.

The list is surprisingly topped by -- this is interesting -- "The True Crime" spoof "American Vandal". Followed by the Brazilian series "3 Percent; the controversial "13 Reasons Why", "Anne with an E" and "Riverdale". The most popular streaming day in 2017 was actually New Year's Day. Netflixstock up sharply so far this year.

And no, Dagen -- "Narcos" wasn't on that list or "The Crown".

BARTIROMO: Neither was "House of Cards".

CASONE: I don't know what to say.

BARTIROMO: Have you seen any of those shows on that list -- Cheryl?

CASONE: No.

BARTIROMO: Neither have I.

MCDOWELL: I haven't either.

CASONE: What's wrong with me?

BARTIROMO: I haven't seen any of those shows.

CASONE: Am I a nerd?

BARTIROMO: How is that possible?

MCDOWELL: I don't know. Something is deeply wrong with me. I did. I'm almost done --

LAYFIELD: I have not seen any of it --

BARTIROMO: Jon? What are these shows?

MCDOWELL: I'm almost done with the second season of "The Crown".

BARTIROMO: How is it?

MCDOWELL: It's not as good as the first season, shall we say. It's a lot about Prince Philip -- kind of boring.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's like "House of Cards" -- it wasn't as good as it got older.

HILSENRATH: No.

MCDOWELL: And now Foghorn Leghorn is gone. I'm talking about Kevin Spacey.

I'll say -- I'll say. I'm Frank Underwood.

LAYFIELD: Is Foghorn Leghorn even around anymore? What a great reference.

MCDOWELL: I'll say - I'll say -- I'll say. There you go.

BARTIROMO: Well, harassment there, then you have harassment scandals hitting the NFL Network as well.

We'll take a break.

When we come back, the fallout after three of the network's analysts received suspensions over new allegations there.

And then the Ball brothers making a fast break to an unexpected destination. Get this -- Lonzo Ball's two youngest sons are going pro just weeks after UCLA suspended one for shoplifting on a trip to China. When the basketball players will be traveling to Lithuania -- that's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Former NFL players are suspended from the NFL Network over sexual assault allegations.

Jared Max with the story now -- Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTS: Maria -- good morning.

Hall of Fame running back Marshall Faulk, along with fellow NFL Network analyst Heath Evans and Ike Taylor have been suspended by the NFL Network after all three were named in sexual misconduct lawsuit by a former NFL Network wardrobe stylist. Jami Cantor who was with the company from 2006 until October 2016. She filed a wrongful termination suit this October. Yesterday filed a further complaint. It alleges sexual harassment and assault.

Cantor claims that Faulk groped and fondled her, inappropriate text messages sent from the others. In addition to inappropriate texts from Donovan McNabb, former NFL quarterback and colleague of Cantor's at the time plus NFL Network executive Eric Weinberger.

McNabb now with ESPN yet to receive potential punishment. Weinberger, president of "The Ringer" placed on indefinite leave.

Monday night football south Florida, Tom Brady going for ninth straight win in ninth straight division title but very Brady celebration pre-empted by the Miami Dolphins defense.

Brady intercepted twice by Xavien Howard last night. Worst game for Brady statistically in four seasons. Jay Cutler three touchdowns for Miami which held New England to 25 rushing yards and didn't allow the Patriots to convert a single third down. That hasn't happened in 26 years. Dolphins win it 27-20.

You know that old saying, if at first you don't succeed, at stealing Louis Vuitton sunglasses on a basketball trip to China, then get suspended by UCLA indefinitely -- try, try again to play ball in another country.

LiAngelo Ball and his younger brother LaMelo Ball are going to be playing ball together. The two younger brothers of L.A. Lakers rookie Lonzo Ball and also the son of LaVar Ball have signed a one year contract to play for a pro team in Lithuania called Prienu Vytautas.

LaMelo was only 16. He was a junior in high school. He dropped out. LiAngelo ball is now 19 years old and probably in need of a new pair sunglasses after that whole mess which became an international incident.

BARTIROMO: Lithuania.

MAX: Yes. Yes. And it's not really about money because they're not going to paid that much. There's reports that maybe guys make about $500 a month. Now you actually get a tax break certainly playing over there. But it's really about spreading the Big Baller brand.

LAYFIELD: Probably the last we're going to hear of them athletically.

MAX: Boy, you wonder, they're still kids. And the coach is said to be the LaVar Ball of Lithuania. I don't know that means.

(CROSSTALK)

LAYFIELD: -- a buffoon that over-hypes himself.

MAX: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Wow. Hey, how is the Olympics? Going high-tech. Humanoid robot Hubo just carried the 2018 Olympic flame. Hubo was given the honor yesterday in South Korea as part of the journey the torch will make before the games start in February. This is one of the 85 robot volunteers assisting in the Winter Games. Pretty cool.

MAX: Maria -- he looks a little bit -- was it the movie "Short Circuit" I think back in the 80s? He looks a little bit or a little R2D2. Check this out. There was new research from McKenzie (ph) that says that as much as one-third of American workforce could be out of work of 2030 because of automation. That 400 million to 800 million people globally could be displaced.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MAX: Maybe some of these robots should have some defects in them so we can keep ourselves employed.

BARTIROMO: That's a real concern.

MAX: Yes. I mean, you know, we laugh about it now but the next 17 year what holds?

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's incredible that they've come up with that -- that it's 2030 that that's when they'll be that pervasive, robotics everywhere.

HILSENRATH: I'm a little skeptical of arguments like that.

BARTIROMO: You are?

HILSENRATH: There were reports like that out ten years ago saying that all of our jobs were going to be outsourced to India. And you know, like radiologists -- we still have plenty of radiologists.

BARTIROMO: But they're doing prostate cancer surgery robotically. I mean the robotics have been very important and a great growth story for health care.

HILSENRATH: It's very important but they're not taking away all the doctors. That's my point.

BARTIROMO: I don't know that they are displacing doctors. Exactly, exactly. Yes.

MAX: Can they tell me who is going to win the Super Bowl?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: They might.

LAYFIELD: You need a flux capacitor for that.

MAX: Exactly. -- 88 miles an hour.

LAYFIELD: That's right.

MAX: With Bill Belichick behind the wheel or answering questions from reporters.

MCDOWELL: Nice "Back to the Future" reference -- and "Back to the Future"

LAYFIELD: Thank you very much. What happened with Tom Savage and the concussion. How did Houston Texas miss that?

MAX: Well, the NFL is really dropping the ball. There's investigations going on because the quarterback -- he shouldn't have been allowed to come back into the game. All of the concern of head safety.

LAYFIELD: And so it was a missed concussion protocol. They're talking about revamping and they dismissed --

MAX: It seems like not everybody has their left hand and right hand working together all the time.

HILSENRATH: Well, a lot of players game that system too, don't they. They get their baseline down so that when they do get hurt they don't get pulled out.

MAX: It doesn't seem like it's all on the same page yet.

BARTIROMO: Jared -- thank you. Catch Jared's sports reports on "FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7" or Sirius Radio Sirius XM 115.

Still to come -- up in smoke. A Southwest flyer threatens passengers midair after crews asked her to snub out her cigarette. The frightening footage from the flight. That's coming up.

And then merger mania, AT&T gearing up for its federal fight over the deal to acquire Time Warner. We talk to AOL co-founder and Revolution chairman Steve Case about what the wave of mega mergers means for the business.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Tuesday. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Tuesday, December 12th, your top stories right now 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

21st Century Fox looks like is losing a bidder for some of its assets. The Wall Street Journal reporting Comcast, Comcast is stepping down, no longer pursuing a deal for key entertainment and media businesses, Disney is still eyeing a deal. It's anybody's guess if maybe Comcast steps away because the deal with Disney is more likely. The very latest on the major mania in the media sector.

Futures this morning show markets will open higher. Dow Industrials at the high of the morning right here, up 40 points. S&P 500 and the Nasdaq also higher by a fraction.

In Europe, similar story money moving into equities this morning, European indices higher across the Board. FT 100 up a quarter of a percent. CAC quarante up almost one half of a percent and the Dax Index up almost a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight, different story. Markets were lower across the board at the close. Worst performer, China.

We are watching oil prices this morning. They are rising as a key European pipeline was shut down for repairs. Crude oil now at 58.41 a barrel.

A southwest flight was diverted over a cigarette. Get this. A passenger caught smoking in the lavatory then he makes death threats to the entire flight. The story coming up.

And then Merriam Webster, out of its word of the year. Find out the dictionary's pick, coming up. What do you think it might be?

Plus, a healthy way to eat Girl Scout cookies. Yoplait now offering thin mint-flavored yogurt. All those stories coming up first this morning.

And first, our top story this half an hour. Will mergers reshape the media business? According to the Wall Street Journal, Comcast confirmed yesterday it is no longer in the race to pursue movie and television assets from 21st Century Fox, leaving Disney as the only serious bidder.

Meanwhile, AT&T gears up for its fight against the Department of Justice over its bid to acquire Time Warner, they say, we want this and we're not going to sell anything to get it.

Joining us this morning is AOL cofounder, former CEO, the current chairman and CEO of Revolution, Steve Case. Steve, it's good to see you.

STEVE CASE, CEO, REVOLUTION: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. And you were around when we saw the last bout of last of mergers in media and telecom and that was obviously a big move for a lot of these companies making these companies bigger. The $164 billion AOL-Time Warner merger was the largest in history.

What do you make of the current M&A climate? What are you seeing out there?

CASE: Well, you say, it does feel like Deja Vu all over again. It's a lot of same discussions happened 20 years ago about the role of content versus distribution. Do you need to be integrated, in particular the battle back then was the debate between this content king or distribution king.

It's pretty clear that the consumer is king and the platforms, the Amazon or Netflixor Facebook that have direct connections to consumers are the once that are advantage. As a result, Disney is basically saying they're going to pull back from Netflixand do their own direct to consumer offering. I think they're trying to bulk up, whether it'd be the Fox assets or other assets to have a credible offering to go directly to consumers. So it's someway this is similar battles that we were hearing 20 years ago.

BARTIROMO: What do you think? So you think the consumer is king, but once again, people are really bidding up content, because -- look at Amazon right now, it's a little different, and, by the way, I can't believe it was 20 years ago. You're right. It was 20 years ago.

Amazon willing to pay out billions and billions of dollars for original content, is that where this is going? Where people are going to start doing more original content or using the sale of established content for example Fox, the Simpsons, you know, so many great shows, this is us, among those being talked about, is that where the value is?

CASE: Well, I think the value as I said is with the services that have direct to consumer offerings. So, how do you bundle together something that's credible which is a mix of brands and content people are already familiar with as well as some original content.

Again, this is not a new idea. HBO, 30 or 40 years ago really was pioneering that highly leverage some of the movies that are already made but invest in original content, Sopranos or other kinds of things to differentiate. So we're continuing to see that move forward.

So the only difference is now that there's a new companies that didn't exist 20 years ago Netflix, Amazon, Facebook, et cetera, Apple as well existed but wasn't really focused so much on media content. So the battle will continue, and the ones that really have that consumer connection, direct consumer connection are likely going to be the winners.

BARTIROMO: Those companies have their own investment arm. You look like an Amazon, it's acquiring. It's got an investment arm, acquiring technology companies.

Let's talk about the fight over net neutrality. I mean, Apple cofounder, Steve Wozniak and the man known as the father of the internet, Vint Cerf are leading a new push to prevent the FCC vote on Thursday.

The group of internet experts are calling on congress to stop the FCC from overturning rules that prevent internet providers from throttling or outright blocking online content. Your thoughts.

CASE: It is also as an old debate. It's sort of like that. Prince song from 1999, the debates in the 90ss around open access. Now the debate is around net neutrality. As a core, it's how do you play the internet as platform for innovation particularly allow disruptive start-ups entrepreneurs all over the country to start innovating and not just have the incumbents kind of lockdown their elites.

So I'm very concerned about net neutrality. I share the view of some of the people who wrote this week saying we need to make sure that the internet remains open for innovation and we err on side of making sure things are tilted in favor of those disruptive, those entrepreneurs that are really trying to launch new things not the existing incumbents trying to kind of protect their lead.

BARTIROMO: And there's this push to invest in the heartland. Your company launching a $150-million fund, focused on investing in start-ups away from the coast in the middle of the country. This is really interesting, especially when you look at backers including big names like Eric Schmidt, Jeff Bezos, Meg Whitman, Howard Schultz. Tell us what your thinking is and these tries of the rest fund.

CASE: Well, I think the -- well, there's great innovation in places like Silicon Valley, and New York City, and Boston. Right now, the vast majority of venture capital goes to those cities. Last year, 75 percent of went to just three states, California, New York and Massachusetts. So the other 47 states, fight over 25 percent, yet there is great entrepreneurs all over the country building great companies.

There is not a lot of venture capital attention. So this Rise of the Rest, we launched about four years ago. It's now accelerating, as you mentioned. We launched last week this new fund and we've got about three dozen of Americas most iconic, respected entrepreneurs and investors, and executives, and families all joining us saying they believe in the idea of Rise of the Rest. They believe there are great entrepreneurs everywhere. They believe there are great investment opportunities everywhere and I hope is what capitalize more focus on middle of the country start-ups and will result in great breakout successes in those communities, also in the process create a lot of jobs, and more hope in those communities.

A lot of people wake up in the morning, feeling like they're anxious about the future. They're not sure what the role of technology is going to be in their family and their community. I want to make sure, by backing startups everywhere, they are creating jobs everywhere, that will really change that dynamic.

BARTIROMO: It's interesting because it's like you look around the world, everybody wanted to be the Silicon Valley, right? Even in Russia, they created this culpable project and yet there are little mini Silicon Valleys innovation hubs throughout the country. You look at Biotech Upstate New York. There's all of these little hubs everywhere, where you actually can tap into real innovation happening not necessarily just Silicon Valley.

CASE: Absolutely. And we've seen that we now there are 33 cities on a rise. The rest road trips that will three, three and a half years. 8,000 miles by bus, so we've been to places like Pittsburgh where a lot of great things are happening with the robotics because of Carnegie-Mellon, buffalo, some of the Biotech things that trade a lot of things around mobility New Orleans. A lot of things around Ag tech, Louisville and St. Louis around Ag tech, farming.

We're seeing innovation happening all over the country. We're trying to change the dynamic on with this rise of the rest to make sure their entrepreneurs in those places have access the capital to grow and scale their companies.

It's long and understood that creativity is wildly dispersed. Opportunity is not and really trying to level the playing field so everybody, everywhere who has an idea really has a shot at American dream.

BARTIROMO: Some of these companies though are more powerful than they ever have been. When you look at the big five, the FANG companies, right? Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, they have so much power, given all of the data, and the information that they have, about us, all.

Do you think the regulatory market changes the regulatory environment changes for technology, given the fact that this is a completely different industry, than just 10 years ago or five years ago, Steve?

CASE: Yes, I think it's beginning to change. We start seeing that the last couple years in the European Union. Brussels got a backing, has starting to slow some of the things happening with some of the big tech, and we're seeing a growing backlash in this country as well.

People are proud of what's happening in Silicon Valley, but also nervous about some of the implications, and including here in Washington, D.C., there's a lot more focus obviously even some congressional committees looking into what was the role of Facebook or other things even in the election.

So it now become so much more central in terms of our everyday lives. Had such a big impact on our economy. It's not surprising that there's more of a focus on the role of big tech if you will. And do I think Silicon Valley needs to be careful.

Last decade, as you well know, Wall Street sort of been the bad guy, I think Silicon Valley is at risk of becoming kind of the new bad guy where people love some of the products and service that come from Silicon Valley. They are a little nervous about some of the steps -- some companies in Silicon Valley are taking.

BARTIROMO: That's what I was asking, because you know, in the last 10 years, we saw the financials basically sit on cash, they were unwilling to do anything with their money, because they didn't know what regulation was around the corner, then you had Dodd-Frank. You wonder if that's going to happen to the technology sector. Now, they're the big spenders. Will they be the big spenders in the future if they've got congressional oversight that's much tougher than they saw in the past? And then, of course, Steve, there's bitcoin.

So you're obviously a student of this industry for a long time 25 years, even more. What do you think of bitcoin, Steve?

CASE: Well, I think it's exciting one though, but take this in their core technologies around block chain. But again, it does feel a little bit like 20 years ago where there's a phenomena, a mania almost around dotcom. Now, here's a little bit of a mania particularly on the trading side around bitcoin and ICOs, things like that.

So think the core technology of block chain ability to track things I think is very important, but I think there is a little bit too much speculation right now and will be interesting to see how things settle.

I saw even yesterday, as he stepped in to stop ICO, an initial coin offering that was happening and this idea that you can raise capital in an unregulated way which has happened recently. I don't think that is sustainable.

So I think we have to separate what's happening in terms of the core technologies like block chain and what's happening in terms of speculation, around that, whether it be bitcoin and ICOs. I think that we need to be a little more careful than we've been in recent months around thinking about that.

BARTIROMO: The Winklevoss brothers yesterday said that this is regulated but I suspect if this action keeps up with bitcoin, it's going to be regulated a lot more.

CASE: I think it's no question. It got talked about and I book in the third. There's next wave of industries and the role of policy regulations playing a deeper role whether it'd be financial services or health care, or some smart cities important aspects of our lives. There's going to be more regulations.

Entrepreneurs hate hearing that particularly in Silicon Valley, but I think it's going to be true and we're going to see that with bitcoin as well, there's no question, the regulators not just in this country but around the world are going to make sure they have adequate protections in place to make sure these technologies, these platforms can have a positive impact on the market as opposed to kind of have potentially some unintended consequences that could be negative.

BARTIROMO: Great insights, Steve. We'll be watching the Rise of the Rest fund. Always great to talk with you, sir. Thank you.

CASE: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you soon. Steve Case there.

Still ahead, smoking leads to a fiery confrontation on Southwest Airlines flight. A passenger threatens to kill everybody onboard after crews asked her to put out her cigarette. The frightening footage that ended in felony charges. That's next.

And then scouting for new flavors. Yoplait teams up with Girl Scouts for a twist on yogurt, back in a minute.

(MUSIC)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news right now. San Francisco mayor, Ed Lee has died. Cheryl Casone with the story now. Cheryl.

CASONE: We're just getting some new details into this, Maria. Lee died early this morning, according to his office. The "San Francisco Examiner" says that Lee died after suffering a heart attack while shopping at a local Safeway store near his home. He was pronounced dead at Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital early this morning.

Lee was a big supporter of San Francisco as sanctuary city. He strongly defended that controversial policy after Kate Steinle was murdered in 2015 by convicted felon who was deported five times.

Mayor Ed Lee dead at the age of 65.

Well, a 24-year-old woman has been arrested after she threatened to kill passengers on a Southwest Airlines flight from Portland to Sacramento. This happened after she was caught smoking in the airplane bathroom.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I swear if you don't -- I will -- kill everybody on this -- plane. I will kill everybody on this -- plane.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, she was physically restrained by crew and passengers until the plane was able to safely land in Sacramento.

Well, amid the spike in reports of sexual assault and harassment in the news lately, feminism is Merriam Webster's word of the year for 2017. The dictionary says the word was the top lookup throughout the year starting as early as January during the women's march on Washington, shortly after the inauguration.

Well Girl Scout cookies are not going to be available for a few months, darn it. But thankfully, Yoplait yogurt is coming out with something to satisfy the cravings. Girl Scout cookies that come in yogurt form. Later this month Yoplait is releasing new flavors inspired by the different cookies, thin mint, peanut butter chocolate, and caramel coconut. Yes, please. Those are your headlines.

BARTIROMO: All right. I'll take it. Thank you, Cheryl.

Coming up next, AR, a reality? We will talk to the company that succeeded with augmented reality where major technology threatened to fail. Wait till you see this, next.

(MUSIC)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. With the holiday shopping season in full swing, now, one of the hottest gifts out there, is augmented and virtual reality headsets.

The company has taking the lead in bringing AR glasses to the market is not Google, by the way, it is a company based out of Rochester, New York called, Vuzix.

So joining me right now is founder and CEO of Vuzix, Paul Travers. Paul, good to see you.

PAUL TRAVERS, CEO, VUZIX: Maria, thanks for having us.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

So, how was Vuzix able to do what other huge tech companies were unable to do for so many years in terms of glasses? We want to look at the spectacles here.

TRAVERS: Well, all these other guys are making things that are massive quite frankly and Vuzix makes lightweight wearable, all-day long kinds of devices. We started the enterprise. We actually have to go all the way back to the defense market.

The defense guys, Special Forces guys, asked if we could make Oakley-style subclasses. Nobody likes to look like a nerd when they put this stuff on. If you look at VR market today, all these things are giant sort of --

BARTIROMO: They're really big on your head. Let me check these out. See how light they are. Can I try this on?

TRAVERS: Yes, please do. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So you have two models here on set. This one is the M300?

TRAVERS: That's actually the Blade.

BARTIROMO: Oh, this is -- OK. So this is the Blade.

TRAVERS: Yes. And it's B to C and consumers, those kinds of things. With those glasses on, you want to take your phone out of your pocket? Put those glasses on, you'll be able to -- Sam, thank you.

BARTIROMO: What I like is that I don't feel like a geek.

TRAVERS: And you don't look like one either.

BARTIROMO: I don't know about that. But tell me what this Blade does.

TRAVERS: So with your phone in your pocket. Imagine you're walking down the street and there's a Pokemon Go character that's up to the right, everybody knows Pokemon Go. Millions of users in a week. The Pokemon Go character comes up, you look and through the glasses you see this character sitting on a street or you're getting directions and the directions are in your glasses. A phone call comes in, you can answer with the glasses on. It's beginnings of leaving your phone in your pocket.

BARTIROMO: Wow. OK. So I don't have to take my phone out with this. This is going to show me -- let's do the other model. This one is the M300 Enterprise Class smart glasses. This is for enterprise, tell us. Put those on. Let me know what it's for.

TRAVERS: That's correct. So these guys are worn like this, around your neck when you're in a warehouse situation that put glasses on, and this becomes effectively the barcode scanner. So instead of taking a handheld barcode scanner, going over to the box --

BARTIROMO: Here, here's the barcode scanner.

TRAVERS: Actually in this particular case, Sam, we're operationally -- well, let me actually run it here. So I'm looking through these glasses and you can see, this is nothing more than a blueprint.

BARTIROMO: Ooh, look at the screen.

TRAVERS: Through the glasses, you can see there's literally a multistory building sitting here that's not real.

BARTIROMO: What we're seeing on that screen is what you're seeing in your glasses?

TRAVERS: That's correct. That's correct. So you can imagine so many applications where this can become a valuable tool.

BARTIROMO: you made the analogy earlier, if you're on a plane, on your -- unloading the baggage from a plane.

TRAVERS: Yes. We worked with folks like SATS at Changi Airport and they have the gate folks wearing these glasses. The pallet comes by, on the side of pallet, a few barcode, barcode kind of a thing. Through these glasses you see all of the information about where that pallet goes on a plane. What section of the plane it belongs in.

If it doesn't belong on that plane, they will have a red marker on the outside of it and just like this building that's not real or marker is not real, but digitally, they can put it in remove it ad at the same time --

BARTIROMO: They know where the baggage goes on the plane.

TRAVERS: They can turn around a plane in one half, the amount of time compared to how they do it today.

BARTIROMO: That's very cool. So Vuzix recently entered into a supply agreement with Toshiba. Tell us about that.

TRAVERS: I can tell you a little bit about that.

BARTIROMO: Come on.

TRAVERS: Well, it's very exciting for me, actually. It's one of the largest, probably orders that smart glasses have seen, quite frankly. Toshiba is a major player in the laptop space. They're coming out with a line of products that are wearable, etch-oriented and they're buying smart glasses from Vuzix.

BARTIROMO: Really? Cool stuff.

TRAVERS: We learn a lot more about that here. It's a multimillion-dollar contract for Vuzix and sometime here in the first quarter, Toshiba will be sharing a lot more. What is the world and 3D?

BARTIROMO: I feel that if you don't have augmented reality or A.I. or some sort, you're going to be left behind, because every industry is using it at this point.

TRAVERS: We have companies getting -- doing things 500 percent ROI, It's really hard to ignore.

BARTIROMO: Cool stuff. Paul, thank you so much.

TRAVERS: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, Paul from Vuzix there.

Still ahead, inventing inspiration. We will talk to a self-made Joy Mangano about her widely popular home shopping network empire.

And the acclaimed 2015 movie loosely based on her life, starring Jennifer Lawrence. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Good Tuesday morning. Welcome back, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

urn:contentItem:5TGB-3GH1-J9XT-P14X-00000-00Alan Friel Comments on Tech Industry's New Interest in Establishing Federal Privacy Regulations2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisAlan Friel Comments on Tech Industry's New Interest in Establishing Federal Privacy Regulations

Cleveland, Ohio: BakerHostetler has issued the following press release: Partner Alan Friel is quoted in an article published Sept. 13, 2018, by The National Journal. The article, “Big Tech Launches Full-Court Press for Federal Privacy Rules,” reports on the tech industry’s support for a federal framework to address data privacy. Friel told the publication that he believes California’s recently passed consumer privacy law -along with similar efforts now being pursued in Illinois and elsewhere – is pushing tech companies to seek federal regulations. “I think that the industry would rather concentrate its efforts in Washington than in a dozen or half-dozen state capitals,” he said. “Another way to say it is, it’s an attempt to pre-empt reckless and ill-advised and costly – maybe well-intentioned, but ill-advised – state efforts at regulation, and to prevent an unworkable patchwork of state laws that make it impractical, if not impossible, for our data-driven economy to operate,” Friel said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KTT-2SK1-JBKN-B3W6-00000-00A lapse in concentration;Deregulation and competition2016-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisSPECIAL REPORTA lapse in concentrationDeregulation and competition

A dearth of competition among firms helps explain wage inequality and a host of other ills

IN "THE FUGITIVE", a 1960s television drama, David Janssen plays Richard Kimble, a doctor wrongly convicted of murdering his wife who escapes on the way to his execution. He claims, but cannot prove, that he encountered a one-armed man minutes before he discovered his wife's dead body. After his escape he drifts from town to town trying to find the ghostly figure and to elude the man obsessed with recapturing him.

The damage that globalisation has done to America's economy is as obvious to some as Dr Kimble's guilt was to his pursuers. Careful academic studies have linked competition by Chinese manufacturers to the growing propensity of prime-aged men to drop out of the labour force. A pillar of trade theory says that increased commerce with labour-rich countries will depress the pay of the low-skilled; and some reckonings of wage inequality in America pin part of the blame on trade and migration. GDP growth has been sluggish during the long hangover from the financial crisis. The globalisation of finance provided the kindling for America's subprime crisis and spread its effects around the world. Globalisation is on the run. But might there be another brigand who bears responsibility for its alleged crimes?

An intriguing line of research identifies an increase in the incidence of economic "rents" (profits over and above the levels needed to justify investment or input of work) as a possible villain. A study last year by Jason Furman, of the Council for Economic Advisers (CEA), and Peter Orszag, a former budget director for Barack Obama, found that the top 10% of firms by profit have pulled away sharply from the rest (see chart). Their return on capital invested rose from more than three times that of the median firm in the 1990s to eight times. This is way above any plausible cost of capital and likely to be pure rent. Those high returns are persistent. More than four-fifths of the firms that made a return of 25% or more in 2003 were still doing so ten years later.

Other research suggests that this increasingly skewed distribution of profits goes a long way to explaining the rise in wage inequality. A paper in 2014 by Erling Bath, Alex Bryson, James Davis and Richard Freeman found that most of the growing dispersion in individual pay since the 1970s is associated with variations in pay between companies, not within them. In other words, the most profitable companies pay handsomely and people who work for them earn more than the rest.

This finding was confirmed in a more recent study by Nicholas Bloom and David Price, both of Stanford University, with others, which found that virtually all of the rise in income inequality is explained by a growing dispersion in average wages paid by firms. This finding, the authors conclude, holds across all industries, regions and firm sizes. One of the most striking implications is that inequality within firms has not changed much: the relationship between managers' and shop-floor workers' pay in each firm is still roughly the same. But the gap between what the average and the best firms pay their workers at all levels has widened. Alan Krueger, of Princeton University, illustrated this point nicely at a presentation he gave while working at the CEA in 2013. Using data from the decade after 2003, he showed that where managers are well paid, so are janitors (see chart).

This wider range of profits is likely to be related to increases in market power. Some of this is due to the rise of internet giants, which dominate their respective markets thanks to network effects. But many of America's industries have also become more concentrated by a slow creep of acquisitions. A study by The Economist earlier this year divided the economy into 900-odd sectors covered by the five-yearly economic census and found that two-thirds of them were more concentrated in 2012 than they had been in 1997. The weighted average share of the total held by the leading four firms in each sector rose from 26% to 32%.

America used to be famous for its workers' willingness to follow the jobs, but they have become far less mobile. A paper by Raven Molloy and Christopher Smith of the Federal Reserve and Abigail Wozniak of the University of Notre Dame finds that over the past three decades migration rates between states have fallen by at least a third for most age groups. For those aged between 20 and 24, the most mobile group, the annual rate of internal migration fell from 5.7% in 1981-89 to 3.3% in 2002-12.

Many of the reasons put forward for this are not wholly convincing. It cannot be the rise of the two-income family, because the trend to less mobility holds for workers of all ages. Nor is it the housing boom and bust: the decline in mobility started long before that, in the early 1990s, and has continued since. It is certainly not trade unions (membership of which has declined), labour-market regulation or unemployment benefits, claims for which have dropped sharply.

A few researchers have made an intriguing link between the decline in labour mobility and wider profit dispersion. The argument has several steps. The average age of established businesses has risen steadily because fewer new firms are formed. Startups have a high labour turnover, but in mature firms fewer people join and leave in any given year. The lower the churn rate of jobs, the fewer the opportunities for job-changers to find new work. So it is possible that less dynamism in American business, characterised by industry concentration and lower job turnover, has reduced the incentive for jobseekers to go and look for work in another state.

Another reason may be rent-seeking within the labour force itself. Another paper from the CEA finds that the share of America's workforce covered by state-licensing laws has risen to 25%, from less than 5% in the 1950s. Much of this red tape is unnecessary. On the most recent estimates, over 1,000 occupations are regulated in at least one state but only 60 are regulated in all states. The scope of the rules vary from state to state. A licensed security guard requires three years of training in Michigan but only around two weeks in most other states, for instance. Licensed workers can command higher pay than the unlicensed kind because entry to the occupation is restricted, so consumers have to pay more.

For much of the past 40 years economic liberals have argued for the dismantling of barriers to the free flow of commerce, such as state monopolies, trade unions and restrictive practices. Such policies have produced some clear successes. In Britain the privatisation of monopoly utilities, such as British Telecom, and the opening up of other sectors to competition was a spur to productivity and innovation, leading to better and cheaper services for customers. In America the deregulation of airlines brought lower fares and an increase in the number of trips. Labour markets in America and Britain became more flexible, and unemployment has generally been lower than in continental Europe.

Deregulation is almost always a difficult task. Those whose interests are hurt by such reforms protest noisily. The political costs quickly become apparent, whereas the gains may not become clear before the next polling day. It is even harder to make changes when so many people feel that the cost of liberalising markets in the past was unfairly distributed. Critics of such liberalisation point to a decline in labour income as a share of GDP as evidence that wage earners have the odds stacked against them. They argue that blue-collar workers provide the flexibility, having to accept lower pay and less job security, whereas white-collar workers and bosses are protected. Increased openness to trade and the growing mobility of capital have made it harder for workers to push for pay rises, so they cling to the jobs they have. In an age of insecurity, it is hard to persuade anyone that they should give up such protections for the greater good.

Market power is supposed to be policed by competition agencies, but they have lost some of their vim, particularly in America, where competition cases are fought out in the courts. A landmark Supreme Court judgment in 2004 said monopoly profits were the just reward for innovation. That has made it harder for trustbusters to root out rent-seeking or block mergers. Most big firms got where they are by being good at what they do, not because of coddling by regulators. But if firms can hold onto their market share for years, they create distortions in the rest of the economy. Incumbent firms are powerful lobbyists.

Big tech firms also have a penchant for so-called "shoot-out" acquisitions, whereby a startup is bought to eliminate a budding rival. For many tech startups and their financiers, a buy-out by one of the big platform companies is a badge of success. But if small firms cannot become independently big, the market power of incumbents is not sufficiently challenged.

Competition policy faces difficult questions in an age of superstar firms that dominate global markets. But the trickiest political problem for reformers is how to inject some dynamism into the economy without getting people even more worried about their livelihoods. Raising import tariffs or closing borders to people and capital is not the answer. Instead, policymakers should encourage more competition while putting in place adequate protections for those who lose out from it.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WRJ-1KC1-JBRC-V4P7-00000-00A lawmaker wants to end ‘social media addiction' by killing features that enable mindless scrolling2019-08-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 0A lawmaker wants to end ‘social media addiction' by killing features that enable mindless scrollingKatie Mettler The Washington Post

WASHINGTON — The youngest senator in Congress, and one of its toughest crusaders against Big Tech, proposed a bill Tuesday meant to curb social media addiction by regulating the techniques that prolong engagement on the platforms. Freshman Sen. Josh Hawley's bill, the Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology (SMART) Act, would make it illegal for social media companies such as Instagram, Twitter and Snapchat to use infinite scroll, autoplay video or techniques like Snapchat's "streaks," which reward a user with badges for repeated use. "Big tech has embraced a business model of addiction," Hawley, a Missouri Republican, said in a statement announcing the bill.

"Too much of the ‘innovation' in this space is designed not to create better products, but to capture more attention by using psychological tricks that make it difficult to look away. This legislation will put an end to that and encourage true innovation by tech companies." The senator has spent his first year in office taking on Big Tech. He grilled Google executives during hearings on the company's data-collection policies. He wrote a scathing letter to the Federal Trade Commission, rebuking regulators for failing to protect consumers from privacy abuse and overreach by Silicon Valley. He proposed a major bipartisan update to the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, which would further curb tech companies' ability to monitor the online behavior of kids. At 39, he is a digital native with a deeper understanding of tech than many of his colleagues. Others in the new class to conquer Capitol Hill have used the very social media platforms he rails against to elevate their voices and steer the online conversation. But Hawley has said he chooses to use them sparingly and has even suggested that society would be better off if social media disappeared. He has called social media a "parasite on productive investment, on meaningful relationships, on a healthy society" and once asked during an NBC interview, "should these platforms exist at all?" The bill doesn't go as far as outright banning social media platforms, but it proposes regulatory measures that would force users to actively choose to engage for prolonged periods rather than being mindlessly sucked into the void. It would require platforms to implement "natural stopping points," or places where a video or post stops and the users are prompted to click or select another piece of content, rather than it appearing or playing automatically. For example, this could affect the way Instagram stories endlessly rotate from one to the next. Hawley's proposal would also require social media companies to create a "user-friendly interface" that would allow users to set time limits or boundaries for themselves and actively display how much time they had spent on any platform. In addition, the bill would require the FTC to produce a report at least every three years on the "issue of Internet addiction" that would explore the ways "social media companies, by exploiting human psychology and brain physiology, interfere with free choices of individuals on the Internet." The SMART Act would give the FTC and secretary of Health and Human Services authority to enforce regulations and establish new rules as the tech environment continues to evolve and innovate. The Internet Association — a trade group that represents global Internet companies including Twitter, Facebook and Snap Inc., which owns Snapchat — said in a statement from President and CEO Michael Beckerman that social media platforms already invest and participate in programs and partnerships that "promote healthy online experiences." Tools to help users regulate their time online already exist, the association added. In his statement, Beckerman said the association backs the Children and Media Research Advancement (CAMRA) Act, which would fund a study by the National Institutes of Health examining the impact of media and technology on children's health. "Funding for independent scientific research is critical to better understand the impact of screen time and identify more ways to enhance people's well-being on and offline," Beckerman's statement said. Previous studies have shown that tech companies use computer design techniques embraced by casinos, such as the idea of "stickiness" — which give "just enough positive feedback to want to return to the game but deny users enough pleasure so that they don't get satiated," Siva Vaidhyanathan told The Washington Post last year. Vaidhyanathan is the author of "Antisocial Media: How Facebook Disconnects Us and Undermines Democracy." A 2018 Pew Research Center study found that 89 percent of teens surveyed that year said they were online "almost constantly" or "several times a day." Forty-five percent said they were online "almost constantly." A different study published in 2019 in the Journal of Behavioral Addictions found that those who reported spending excessive time on Facebook were more likely to take risky gambles, performing on a psychological test with the same impulses as someone addicted to drugs. Hawley's bill does not yet have any co-sponsors, reported the Hill.

Getty Images The Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology (SMART) Act would make it illegal for social media companies such as Instagram, Twitter and Snapchat to use infinite scroll, autoplay video or techniques like Snapchat's "streaks," which reward a user with badges for repeated use.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WP8-W4B1-JB4M-V0DY-00000-00A lawmaker wants to end 'social media addiction' by killing features that enable mindless scrolling;Sen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) has proposed a bill taking on Big Tech's techniques.2019-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisA lawmaker wants to end 'social media addiction' by killing features that enable mindless scrollingSen. Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) has proposed a bill taking on Big Tech's techniques.Katie Mettler

The youngest senator in Congress, and one of its toughest crusaders against Big Tech, proposed a bill Tuesday meant to curb social media addiction by regulating the techniques that prolong engagement on the platforms.

Freshman Sen. Josh Hawley's bill, the Social Media Addiction Reduction Technology (SMART) Act, would make it illegal for social media companies such as Instagram, Twitter and Snapchat to use infinite scroll, autoplay video or techniques like Snapchat's "streaks," which reward a user with badges for repeated use.

"Big tech has embraced a business model of addiction," Hawley, a Missouri Republican, said in a statement announcing the bill. "Too much of the 'innovation' in this space is designed not to create better products, but to capture more attention by using psychological tricks that make it difficult to look away. This legislation will put an end to that and encourage true innovation by tech companies."

The senator has spent his first year in office taking on Big Tech. He grilled Google executives during hearings on the company's data-collection policies. He wrote a scathing letter to the Federal Trade Commission, rebuking regulators for failing to protect consumers from privacy abuse and overreach by Silicon Valley. He proposed a major bipartisan update to the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, which would further curb tech companies' ability to monitor the online behavior of kids.

At 39, he is a digital native with a deeper understanding of tech than many of his colleagues. Others in the new class to conquer Capitol Hill have used the very social media platforms he rails against to elevate their voices and steer the online conversation. But Hawley has said he chooses to use them sparingly and has even suggested that society would be better off if social media disappeared.

He has called social media a "parasite on productive investment, on meaningful relationships, on a healthy society" and once asked during an NBC interview, "should these platforms exist at all?"

The bill doesn't go as far as outright banning social media platforms, but it proposes regulatory measures that would force users to actively choose to engage for prolonged periods rather than being mindlessly sucked into the void.

It would require platforms to implement "natural stopping points," or places where a video or post stops and the users are prompted to click or select another piece of content, rather than it appearing or playing automatically. For example, this could affect the way Instagram stories endlessly rotate from one to the next.

Hawley's proposal would also require social media companies to create a "user-friendly interface" that would allow users to set time limits or boundaries for themselves and actively display how much time they had spent on any platform.

In addition, the bill would require the FTC to produce a report at least every three years on the "issue of Internet addiction" that would explore the ways "social media companies, by exploiting human psychology and brain physiology, interfere with free choices of individuals on the Internet."

The SMART Act would give the FTC and secretary of Health and Human Services authority to enforce regulations and establish new rules as the tech environment continues to evolve and innovate.

The Internet Association - a trade group that represents global Internet companies including Twitter, Facebook and Snap Inc., which owns Snapchat - said in a statement from President and Chief Executive Michael Beckerman that social media platforms already invest and participate in programs and partnerships that "promote healthy online experiences." Tools to help users regulate their time online already exist, the association added.

In his statement, Beckerman said the association backs the Children and Media Research Advancement (CAMRA) Act, which would fund a study by the National Institutes of Health examining the impact of media and technology on children's health.

"Funding for independent scientific research is critical to better understand the impact of screen time and identify more ways to enhance people's well-being on and offline," Beckerman's statement said.

Previous studies have shown that tech companies use computer design techniques embraced by casinos, such as the idea of "stickiness" - which give "just enough positive feedback to want to return to the game but deny users enough pleasure so that they don't get satiated," Siva Vaidhyanathan told The Washington Post last year. Vaidhyanathan is the author of "Antisocial Media: How Facebook Disconnects Us and Undermines Democracy."

A 2018 Pew Research Center study found that 89 percent of teens surveyed that year said they were online "almost constantly" or "several times a day." Of that 89 percent, 45 percent said they were online "almost constantly."

A different study published in 2019 in the Journal of Behavioral Addictions found that those who reported spending excessive time on Facebook were more likely to take risky gambles, performing on a psychological test with the same impulses as someone addicted to drugs.

Hawley's bill does not yet have any co-sponsors, reported the Hill.

Read more:

Opinion | Tech addiction is real. We psychologists need to take it seriously.

The Technology 202: New study finds social media junkies make riskier decisions

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XBK-6B01-DXH2-628K-00000-00A Lawyer For Singer Lizzo Announced A Lawsuit Involving Her Hit Song "Truth Hurts", CBS2019-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:08:43ZLexisNexisCBS MORNING NEWS4:00 AM ESTNEWS102404cb.400A Lawyer For Singer Lizzo Announced A Lawsuit Involving Her Hit Song "Truth Hurts", CBSAnne-marie Green, Diane King Hall

Stocks closed higher yesterday with help from health care and communications companies.

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: A lawyer for singer Lizzo announced a lawsuit involving her hit song "Truth Hurts." It establishes that two songwriters, Justin and Jeremiah Raisen, as well as Justin "Yves" Rothman, do not deserve credit for the song as they have been claiming. The songwriters say they contributed to a signature line about taking a DNA test. Meanwhile, Lizzo did say she`s sharing writing credit on the song with the actual creator of that line, Mina Lioness. Lizzo said on social media Lioness is the only one who deserves the credit.

On the CBS MoneyWatch now, new criticism for the FAA, and a Google computer achieves a breakthrough. Diane King Hall is at the New York Stock Exchange with that and more. Good morning, Diane.

DIANE KING HALL: Good morning, Anne-Marie. Well, earnings season is full steam ahead. Big tech takes center stage today with quarterly results due from Amazon, Twitter, and Intel. Also reporting today are American and Southwest Airlines. Now, stocks closed higher yesterday with help from health care and communications companies. The Dow rose forty-five points. The S&P 500 gained eight. And the NASDAQ added fifteen.

A new report says the FAA must restore, quote, "public confidence" in aircraft certification efforts following two deadly crashes involving Boeing 737 Max. According to Reuters, the report by the transportation department`s inspector general said the FAA faces a, quote, "significant oversight challenge to ensure that companies conducting those tests maintain high standards and comply with FAA safety regulations."

Now, call it a quantum leap. Google says it has achieved a breakthrough in quantum computing. Scientists say they developed an experimental processor that performed a complicated calculation in two hundred seconds. The same calculation would take about ten thousand years to complete by today`s fastest supercomputer. If they head to the mainstream, quantum computers could perform important work like designing new drugs at the molecular level, optimizing financial investments and speeding up package delivery.

And Target has unveiled its holiday plans. The retail giant will offer free shipping for items bought between November 1st and December 22nd with no minimum purchase required. Target is also opening Disney shops inside more than two dozen of its stores. Not to be outdone, rival Walmart is kicking off its holiday shopping season with deals starting tomorrow. Walmart says it wants to help consumers get an early start on purchasing gifts with new and expanded services. Those include more exclusive toys and visits from Santa. Anne-Marie.

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: All right. Diane King Hall at the New York Stock Exchange. Thanks, Diane.

DIANE KING HALL: You got it.

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: Just want to get through Thanksgiving first. All right.

Still ahead, a first pitch with a twist. Gymnast Simone Biles delivers an unbelievable first pitch before game two of the World Series.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: Simone Biles made the crowd flip for her as much as she did for them. Just before game two of the World Series last night between the Nationals and the Astros, the Texas native and Olympic champion did a spinning flip and then she threw the ceremonial first pitch. The Nationals crushed the home team 12-3 to take a commanding 2-0 lead in the series.

And this morning, Katherine Johnson, a trailblazing reporter for the Associated Press, is being remembered. The award-winning journalist died yesterday morning in Atlanta. Her intrepid coverage of the Civil Rights movement and other important stories led to a string of legendary scoops. She was the only journalist allowed inside Martin Luther King Jr.`s home the day he was assassinated. Katherine Johnson was ninety-three.

And coming up on CBS THIS MORNING in a broadcast exclusive, Gayle King talks with legendary rocker Bruce Springsteen about his directorial debut.

I`m Anne-Marie Green. This is the CBS MORNING NEWS.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)
